1.verse: The Beginning of the World - ·In the beginning [or In the beginning when] God created [this Hebrew verb is used only when God is the one creating] the ·sky [heavens] and the earth.

2.verse: ·The [or…the] earth ·had no form and was empty [or was a formless void]. Darkness covered the ·ocean [deep], and ·God’s Spirit [or a mighty wind] was ·moving [hovering] over the water.

3.verse: Then God said, “Let there be light,” and there was light.

4.verse: God saw that the light was good, so he ·divided [separated] the light from the darkness.

5.verse: God ·named [called] the light “day” and the darkness “night.” ·Evening passed, and morning came [There was evening and there was morning; in the OT a day begins at nightfall]. This was the first day.

6.verse: Then God said, “Let there be ·something to divide the water in two [a firmament/dome/expanse in the midst of the waters to separate/divide the waters from the waters].”

7.verse: So God made the ·air [firmament; dome; expanse; rain clouds] and placed some of the water above the ·air [firmament; dome; expanse] and some below it [referring to the rain and the oceans, lakes, and rivers].

8.verse: God ·named [called] the ·air [firmament/dome/expanse] “·sky [heaven].” Evening passed, and morning came [1:5]. This was the second day.

9.verse: Then God said, “Let the water under the ·sky [heavens] be gathered together so the dry land will appear.” And it happened.

10.verse: God ·named [called] the dry land “earth” and [he called] the water that was gathered together “seas.” God saw that this was good.

11.verse: Then God said, “Let the earth produce ·plants [vegetation]—some to make grain for seeds and ·others to make fruits with seeds in them. Every seed will produce more of its own kind of plant [fruit trees on earth bearing fruit according to its own kind/species that has seed in them].” And it happened.

12.verse: The earth ·produced [brought forth] plants with grain for seeds and trees that made fruits with seeds in them. ·Each seed grew its own kind of plant […according to its kind/species]. God saw that all this was good.

13.verse: Evening passed, and morning came [1:5]. This was the third day.

14.verse: Then God said, “Let there be lights in the ·sky [firmament/dome/expanse of the heavens] to ·separate [divide] day from night. ·These lights will be used for [They will be] signs, seasons, days, and years.

15.verse: They will be in the ·sky [firmament/dome/expanse] to give light to the earth.” And it happened.

16.verse: So God made the two ·large [great] lights. He made the ·brighter [greater] light to rule the day and made the ·smaller [lesser] light to rule the night. ·He also made the stars […and the stars].

17.verse: God put all these in the sky to shine on the earth,

18.verse: to rule over the day and over the night, and to ·separate [divide] the light from the darkness. God saw that all these things were good.

19.verse: Evening passed, and morning came [1:5]. This was the fourth day.

20.verse: Then God said, “Let the water ·be filled with living things [swarm with living creatures], and let birds fly in the ·air [firmament/dome/expanse] above the earth.”

21.verse: So God created [1:1] the large sea ·animals [or monsters] and every living thing that ·moves [swarms] in the sea. The sea is filled with these living things, with each one ·producing more of its own kind [according to its kind/species]. He also ·made [or created; 1:1] every bird that flies, and each bird ·produced more of its own kind [according to its kind/species]. God saw that this was good.

22.verse: God blessed them and said, “·Have many young ones so that you may grow in number [Be fruitful and multiply]. ·Fill […and fill] the water of the seas, and let the birds ·grow in number [multiply] on the earth.”

23.verse: Evening passed, and morning came [1:5]. This was the fifth day.

24.verse: Then God said, “Let the earth be filled with ·animals [living creatures], ·each producing more of its own kind [according to their kind/species]. Let there be ·tame animals [beasts; livestock] and small crawling animals and wild animals, ·and let each produce more of its kind [according to their kind/species].” And it happened.

25.verse: So God made the wild animals, the ·tame animals [beasts; livestock], and all the small crawling animals ·to produce more of their own kind [according to their kind/species]. God saw that this was good.

26.verse: Then God said, “Let us make human beings in our image and likeness. And let them ·rule [have dominion] over the fish in the sea and the birds in the ·sky [heavens], over the ·tame animals [beasts; livestock], over all the earth, and over all the small crawling animals on the earth.”

27.verse: So God created [1:1] ·human beings [man; the Hebrew adam can mean human beings, humankind, person, man, or the proper name Adam] in his image [reflecting God’s nature/character and representing him in the world]. In the image of God he created them. He created them male and female.

28.verse: God blessed them and said [to them], “·Have many children and grow in number [Be fruitful and multiply]. ·Fill […and fill] the earth and ·be its master [subdue it]. ·Rule [Have dominion] over the fish in the sea and over the birds in the ·sky [heavens] and over every living thing that moves on the earth.”

29.verse: God said, “Look, I have given you all the plants that have grain for seeds [on the face of the earth] and all the trees whose fruits have seeds in them. They will be food for you.

30.verse: I have given all the green plants as food for every wild animal, every bird of the ·air [sky; heavens], and every small ·crawling [creeping] animal.” And it happened.

31.verse: God looked at everything he had made, and it was ·very [exceedingly] good. Evening passed, and morning came [1:5]. This was the sixth day.

1.verse: The Seventh Day—Rest - So the ·sky [heavens], the earth, and all ·that filled them [their hosts] were ·finished [completed].

2.verse: By the seventh day God ·finished [completed] the work he had been doing, so he ·rested [or ceased] from all his work [he had done].

3.verse: God blessed the seventh day and ·made it a holy day [consecrated it; set it apart], because on that day he ·rested [or ceased] from all the work he had done in creating [1:1] the world.

4.verse: The First People - ·This is the story [These are the generations; introduces a new section of the book; see also 5:1; 6:9; 10:1; 11:10, 27; 25:12, 19; 36:1, 9] of the creation of the ·sky [heavens] and the earth. When the ·LORD God [Yahweh Elohim; Elohim is the common term for God; LORD (capital letters) represents the divine name YHWH, usually pronounced “Yahweh”; see Ex. 3:14–15] first made the earth and the ·sky [heavens],

5.verse: there were still no plants on the earth. Nothing was growing in the fields because the LORD God had not yet made it rain on the land. And there was no person to ·care for [or till; work] the ground,

6.verse: but a ·mist [or stream] would rise up from the earth and water all the ground.

7.verse: Then the LORD God took dust from the ground and formed a man from it [there is wordplay between “ground” (adama) and “man” (adam)]. He breathed the breath of life into the man’s nose, and the man became a living person.

8.verse: ·Then the LORD God [or The LORD God had] planted a garden in the east [probably east of Palestine], in a place called Eden [related to a word meaning “luxurious”], and put the man he had formed into it.

9.verse: The LORD God caused every ·beautiful [desirous to see] tree and every tree that was good for food to grow out of the ground. In the middle of the garden, God put the tree ·that gives life [of life] and also the tree ·that gives the knowledge [of the knowledge] of good and evil.

10.verse: A river flowed through Eden and watered the garden. From there the river ·branched out [divides] to become four ·rivers [heads].

11.verse: The first river, named Pishon [otherwise unknown], flows around the whole land of Havilah [otherwise unknown], where there is gold.

12.verse: The gold of that land is excellent. Bdellium [a sweet-smelling resin like myrrh] and onyx [a precious stone] are also found there.

13.verse: The second river, named Gihon [a small stream in Jerusalem (1 Kin. 1:33), but here perhaps referring to another river], flows around the whole land of Cush [often referring to Ethiopia, but here likely a place in Mesopotamia; see 10:7].

14.verse: The third river, named Tigris [a major river in Mesopotamia], flows out of Assyria [in northern Mesopotamia (present-day Iraq)] toward the east. The fourth river is the Euphrates [a major river in Mesopotamia; the location of Eden is uncertain, but this passage suggests Mesopotamia].

15.verse: The LORD God [took and] put ·the man [or Adam; 1:27] in the garden of Eden to ·care for [or till] it and ·work [take care of; look after] it.

16.verse: The LORD God commanded him, “You may eat the fruit from ·any tree [or all the trees] in the garden,

17.verse: but you must not eat the fruit from the tree ·which gives the [of the] knowledge of good and evil [eating from this tree would make Adam, not God, the determiner of right and wrong]. If you ever eat fruit from that tree, you will [certainly] die!”

18.verse: The First Woman - Then the LORD God said, “It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a helper [in the sense of a partner or ally; the word does not imply subordinate status; see Ps. 79:9] who ·is right for [is suitable for; corresponds with] him.”

19.verse: From the ground God formed every ·wild animal [animal of the field] and every bird in the ·sky [heavens], and he brought them to the man ·so the man could name them [to see what he would call them]. Whatever the man called each living thing, that became its name.

20.verse: The man gave names to all the ·tame animals [beasts; livestock], to the birds in the ·sky [heavens], and to all the ·wild animals [animals of the field]. But ·Adam [or the man; 1:27] did not find a helper that was right for him [2:18].

21.verse: So the LORD God caused ·the man to sleep very deeply [a deep sleep to fall on the man/Adam], and while he was asleep, God removed one of the man’s ·ribs [or sides]. Then God closed up the man’s skin at the place where he took the ·rib [or side].

22.verse: The LORD God used the ·rib [or side] from the man to ·make [build; construct] a woman, and then he brought the woman to the man.

23.verse: And the man said, “·Now, this is someone whose bones came from my bones, whose body came from my body [At last, this is bone of my bones and flesh of my flesh]. ·I will call her [She will be called] ‘woman [Hebrew ‘ishshah],’ because she was taken out of man [Hebrew ‘ish].”

24.verse: So a man will leave his father and mother [in the sense of a new primary loyalty] and be united with his wife, and the two will become one ·body [flesh].

25.verse: The man and his wife were naked, but they were not ashamed.

1.verse: The Beginning of Sin - Now the ·snake [serpent] was the most ·clever [shrewd; cunning; crafty] of all the wild animals the LORD God had made. One day the snake said to the woman, “Did God really say that you must not eat fruit from any tree in the garden?”

2.verse: The woman answered the snake [3:1], “We may eat fruit from the trees in the garden.

3.verse: But God told us, ‘You must not eat fruit from the tree that is in the middle of the garden [the tree of the knowledge of good and evil]. You must not even touch it [Eve was adding to the divine command], or you will die.’ ”

4.verse: But the snake [3:1] said to the woman, “You will [most certainly] not die.

5.verse: [For] God knows that if you eat ·the fruit from that tree [from it], [your eyes will be opened and] you will ·learn about [experience; know about] good and evil and you will be like God!”

6.verse: The woman saw that the tree was ·beautiful [pleasing to the eyes], that its fruit was good ·to eat [for food], and that it would make her wise. So she took some of its fruit and ate it. She also gave some of the fruit to her husband who was with her [apparently he was present but silent while the woman spoke to the snake], and he ate it.

7.verse: Then, ·it was as if their eyes [the eyes of both of them] were opened. They ·realized [knew] they were naked, so they sewed fig leaves together and made ·something to cover [loincloths for] themselves [Rom. 5:12–21].

8.verse: Then they heard the [sound of the] LORD God walking in the garden during the cool part of the day, and the man and his wife hid from the LORD God among the trees in the garden.

9.verse: But the LORD God called to the man and said, “Where are you?”

10.verse: The man answered, “I heard ·you walking in the garden [your voice/sound], and I was afraid because I was naked, so I hid.”

11.verse: ·God [He] asked, “Who told you that you were naked? Did you eat fruit from the tree from which I commanded you not to eat?”

12.verse: The man said, “You gave this woman to me and she gave me fruit from the tree, so I ate it.”

13.verse: Then the LORD God said to the woman, “·How could you have done such a thing [What is this you have done]?” She answered, “The snake ·tricked [deceived; 1 Tim. 2:14] me, so I ate the fruit.”

14.verse: The LORD God said to the ·snake [serpent], “Because you did this, a curse will be put on you. You will be cursed as no other animal, ·tame [beasts; livestock] or ·wild [of the field], will ever be. You will ·crawl [go] on your ·stomach [belly], and you will eat dust all the days of your life.

15.verse: I will ·make you and the woman enemies to each other [place hostility/enmity between you and the woman]. Your ·descendants [seed] and her ·descendants [seed] will be enemies. ·One of her descendants [He] will crush your head, and you will ·bite [strike; bruise; crush] his heel [Rom. 16:20; Rev. 12:9].”

16.verse: Then God said to the woman, “I will ·cause you to have much trouble [or increase your pain] ·when you are pregnant [in childbearing], and when you give birth to children, you will have great pain. You will greatly desire [the word implies a desire to control; 4:7] your husband, but he will rule over you.”

17.verse: Then God said to ·the man [or Adam; 1:27], “You listened to what your wife said, and you ate fruit from the tree from which I commanded you not to eat. “·So I will put a curse on [Cursed is] the ground, and you will have to ·work very hard [toil; labor] for your food. In pain you will eat its food all the days of your life.

18.verse: The ground will produce thorns and ·weeds [thistles] for you, and you will eat the plants of the field.

19.verse: ·You will sweat and work hard for [By the sweat of your brow you will eat] your food. Later you will return to the ground, because you were taken from it. You are dust, and ·when you die, you will return to the dust [to dust you will return; 1 Cor. 15:21-22, 40–45].”

20.verse: The man named his wife Eve [the name derives from an early form of the verb “to live”], because she was the mother of all the living.

21.verse: The LORD God made clothes from animal skins for ·the man [or Adam; 1:27] and his wife and dressed them.

22.verse: Then the LORD God said, “Humans have become like one of us [referring to the supernatural heavenly beings, God and the angels]; they know good and evil. We must keep them from [putting forth their hand and taking and] eating some of the fruit from the tree of life, or they will live forever.”

23.verse: So the LORD God ·forced [expelled] Adam out of the garden of Eden to ·work [till; or care for; 2:5] the ground from which he was taken.

24.verse: After God ·forced [drove] humans out of the garden, he placed ·angels [cherubim; particularly powerful spiritual beings] and a sword of fire that flashed around in every direction on its eastern border. ·This kept people from getting […to guard the way] to the tree of life.

1.verse: The First Family - ·Adam [The man; 1:27] ·had sexual relations with [knew] his wife Eve, and she ·became pregnant [conceived] and gave birth to Cain. Eve said, “With the LORD’s help, I have ·given birth to [produced; or acquired; the verb resembles Cain’s name] a man.”

2.verse: After that, Eve gave birth to Cain’s brother Abel [resembles the word for vapor or breath]. Abel took care of flocks, and Cain ·became a farmer [was a tiller/worker of the ground].

3.verse: ·Later [In due course; At the end of the days], Cain brought some ·food [produce; fruit] from the ground as a ·gift [tribute; Lev. 2] to God.

4.verse: Abel brought the ·best parts [fat portions; Lev. 3:16] from some of the firstborn of his flock [Heb. 11:4]. The LORD ·accepted [looked with favor on] Abel and his ·gift [tribute],

5.verse: but he did not ·accept [look with favor on] Cain and his ·gift [tribute]. So Cain became very angry and ·felt rejected [or felt dejected; his face/countenance fell].

6.verse: The LORD asked Cain, “Why are you angry? Why ·do you look so unhappy [has your face/countenance fallen; 4:5]?

7.verse: If you do things ·well [correctly; appropriately], ·I will [will I not…?] accept you, but if you do not do them ·well [correctly; appropriately], sin is ·ready to attack you [crouching at the door]. Sin ·wants [desires to control; 3:16] you, but you must rule over it.”

8.verse: Cain said to his brother Abel, “Let’s go out into the field.” While they were out in the field, Cain ·attacked [rose up against] his brother Abel and killed him [Matt. 23:35; Luke 11:51; Heb. 12:24; 1 John 3:11–12; Jude 11].

9.verse: Later, the LORD said to Cain, “Where is your brother Abel?” Cain answered, “I don’t know. ·Is it my job to take care of my brother [Am I my brother’s keeper]?”

10.verse: Then the LORD said, “What have you done? Your brother’s blood is crying out to me from the ground.

11.verse: And now you will be cursed ·in your work with [and banished from] the ground, ·the same ground where your brother’s blood fell and where your hands killed him [which has opened its mouth to take the blood of your brother from your hand].

12.verse: You will ·work [till] the ground, but it will not ·grow good crops [yield its strength] for you anymore, and you will ·wander around [be a fugitive and a wanderer/homeless wanderer] on the earth.”

14.verse: Today you have forced me ·to stop working [from] the ground, and now I ·must hide from you [or will be hidden from your face]. I ·must wander around [will be a fugitive and wanderer/homeless wanderer] on the earth, and anyone who ·meets [finds] me can kill me.”

15.verse: The LORD said to Cain, “No! If anyone kills you, I will ·punish [avenge] that person seven times more.” Then the LORD put a mark [the nature of the mark is uncertain] on Cain warning anyone who ·met [finds] him not to kill him.

16.verse: Cain’s Family - So Cain went away from the LORD and lived in the land of Nod [resembles a Hebrew word meaning “wanderer”], east of Eden.

17.verse: He ·had sexual relations with [knew; 4:1] his wife, and she ·became pregnant [conceived] and gave birth to Enoch. At that time ·Cain [he] was building a city, which he named after his son Enoch.

18.verse: ·Enoch had a son named [To Enoch was born; and so through the rest of the genealogy] Irad, Irad had a son named Mehujael, Mehujael had a son named Methushael, and Methushael had a son named Lamech.

19.verse: Lamech ·married [took] two ·women [or wives], [the name of the first was] Adah and [the name of the second was] Zillah.

20.verse: Adah gave birth to Jabal, who ·became the first person to [was the father of those who] live in tents and raise ·cattle [livestock].

21.verse: Jabal’s brother was Jubal, the ·first person to [father of all who] play the ·harp [or lyre] and ·flute [pipe].

22.verse: Zillah gave birth to Tubal-Cain, who made tools out of bronze and iron. The sister of Tubal-Cain was Naamah.

23.verse: Lamech said to his wives: “Adah and Zillah, hear my voice! You wives of Lamech, listen to what I say. I killed a man for wounding me, a young man for hitting me.

24.verse: If ·Cain’s killer is punished [Cain is avenged] seven times [4:15], then ·Lamech’s killer will be punished [Lamech will be avenged] seventy-seven times.” [Lamech falsely thought he could get away with murder.]

25.verse: Adam and Eve Have a New Son - Adam ·had sexual relations with [knew; 4:1] his wife Eve again, and she gave birth to a son. She named him Seth [related to the Hebrew word for “give” or “appoint”] and said, “God has ·given [appointed for] me another child. He will take the place of Abel, who was killed by Cain.”

26.verse: Seth also had a son, and they named him Enosh. At that time people began to ·pray to [call on the name of] the LORD.

1.verse: Adam’s Family History - This is the ·family history [book of the generations; see 2:4] of Adam. When God created ·human beings [humankind; man; Hebrew Adam; 1:27–28], he made them in his own likeness.

2.verse: He created them male and female, and on that day he blessed them and named them ·human beings [humankind; or Adam; man].

3.verse: When Adam was 130 years old, he became the father of another son in his likeness and image [indicating he was like Adam and that he also bore God’s image], and Adam named him Seth [4:25].

4.verse: After Seth was born, Adam lived 800 years and had other sons and daughters.

5.verse: So Adam lived a total of 930 years, and then he died [the long lives in this genealogy indicate God’s blessing; these names are also in Jesus’ genealogy in Luke 3:36–38].

6.verse: When Seth was 105 years old, he had a son named Enosh.

7.verse: After Enosh was born, Seth lived 807 years and had other sons and daughters.

8.verse: So Seth lived a total of 912 years, and then he died.

9.verse: When Enosh was 90 years old, he had a son named Kenan.

10.verse: After Kenan was born, Enosh lived 815 years and had other sons and daughters.

11.verse: So Enosh lived a total of 905 years, and then he died.

12.verse: When Kenan was 70 years old, he had a son named Mahalalel.

13.verse: After Mahalalel was born, Kenan lived 840 years and had other sons and daughters.

14.verse: So Kenan lived a total of 910 years, and then he died.

15.verse: When Mahalalel was 65 years old, he had a son named Jared.

16.verse: After Jared was born, Mahalalel lived 830 years and had other sons and daughters.

17.verse: So Mahalalel lived a total of 895 years, and then he died.

18.verse: When Jared was 162 years old, he had a son named Enoch.

19.verse: After Enoch was born, Jared lived 800 years and had other sons and daughters.

20.verse: So Jared lived a total of 962 years, and then he died.

21.verse: When Enoch was 65 years old, he had a son named Methuselah.

22.verse: After Methuselah was born, Enoch walked with God 300 years more and had other sons and daughters.

23.verse: So Enoch lived a total of 365 years.

24.verse: Enoch walked with God [he had a close relationship with God; Heb. 11:5–6]; one day Enoch could not be found, because God took him [like Elijah (2 Kin. 2:11), he did not die].

25.verse: When Methuselah was 187 years old, he had a son named Lamech.

26.verse: After Lamech was born, Methuselah lived 782 years and had other sons and daughters.

27.verse: So Methuselah lived a total of 969 years, and then he died.

28.verse: When Lamech was 182, he had a son.

29.verse: Lamech named his son Noah [the name resembles the Hebrew word for “rest”] and said, “He will ·comfort us in [or give us rest from] our work, which comes from the ground the LORD has cursed [3:17–19].”

30.verse: After Noah was born, Lamech lived 595 years and had other sons and daughters.

31.verse: So Lamech lived a total of 777 years, and then he died.

32.verse: After Noah was 500 years old, he became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth [9:18–29; 10].

1.verse: The Human Race Grows More Evil - The number of people on earth began to ·grow [multiply], and daughters were born to them.

2.verse: When the ·sons of God [may refer to godly men among Seth’s descendants (ch. 5), or noble men, or angels] saw that ·these girls [the daughters of men/human beings; either evil women among Cain’s descendants (4:17–24), poor women, or simply mortal women] were beautiful, they married any of them they chose [though their identity is unclear, their marriage clearly violated a boundary].

3.verse: The LORD said, “My Spirit will not ·remain in [or contend with] human beings forever, because they are ·flesh [mortal]. ·They will live [Their days will be] only 120 years.”

4.verse: The ·Nephilim [fallen ones; the significance of the name is unclear] were on the earth in those days and also later. That was when the sons of God ·had sexual relations with [came in to] the daughters of ·human beings [man; Hebrew: Adam; 1:27–28]. These women gave birth to children ·who became famous [men of a name] and were the mighty warriors of long ago. [The Nephilim of Num. 13:31–33, though not related genealogically, were giants, suggesting these pre-flood Nephilim were also.]

5.verse: The LORD saw that the human beings on the earth were very ·wicked [evil] and that ·everything they thought about [every inclination of their mind/heart] was ·evil [wicked].

6.verse: He ·was sorry [regretted] he had made human beings on the earth, and his heart was filled with pain.

7.verse: So the LORD said, “I will ·destroy [wipe/blot out; exterminate] all human beings that I ·made [created; 1:1] on the earth. And I will destroy every animal and everything that ·crawls [creeps] on the earth and the birds of the ·air [sky; heavens], because I ·am sorry [regret] I have made them.”

8.verse: But Noah ·pleased [found grace/favor in the eyes of] the LORD.

9.verse: Noah and the Great Flood - This is the family history [2:4] of Noah. Noah was a ·good [righteous; just] man, the most ·innocent [blameless; Job 1:1] man of his ·time [generation], and he walked with God [5:24].

10.verse: He had three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth [9:18–10:32].

11.verse: ·People on earth [The earth] did what ·God said was evil [was corrupt before God], and ·violence was everywhere [the earth was filled with violence].

12.verse: When God saw that [the earth was corrupt because] ·everyone [all flesh] on the earth ·did only evil [was corrupt],

13.verse: God said to Noah, “·I have decided to bring an end to all living creatures [The end of all flesh is coming before me]. Because people have made the earth full of violence, I will destroy all of them from the ·earth [land].

14.verse: ·Build [Make] ·a boat [an ark] of ·cypress [or gopher; the precise meaning is uncertain] wood for yourself. Make rooms in it and cover it inside and outside with ·tar [pitch].

15.verse: This is how ·big I want you to build the boat [you should make it]: ·four hundred fifty feet [three hundred cubits] long, ·seventy-five feet [fifty cubits] wide, and ·forty-five feet [thirty cubits] high.

16.verse: Make an opening around the top of the boat [probably a window] that is ·eighteen inches [a cubit] high from the edge of the roof down. Put a door in the side of the boat. Make an ·upper, middle, and lower [lower, second, and third] deck in it.

17.verse: I will bring a flood of water on the earth to destroy all ·living things [flesh] that live under ·the sky [heaven], including everything that has the breath of life. Everything on the earth will die.

18.verse: But I will ·make [establish] an ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with you—you, your sons, your wife, and your sons’ wives will all go into the boat.

19.verse: Also, you must bring into the ·boat [ark] two of ·every living thing [all flesh], male and female. Keep them alive with you.

20.verse: Two of every kind of bird, animal, and ·crawling [creeping] thing will come to you to be kept alive.

21.verse: Also ·gather [take] some of every kind of food and store it on the boat as food for you and the animals.”

22.verse: Noah did everything that God commanded him.

1.verse: The Flood Begins - Then the LORD said to Noah, “I have seen that you ·are the best person [alone are righteous] among ·the people of this time [this generation], so you and your ·family [household] can go into the ·boat [ark].

2.verse: Take with you seven pairs, each male with its female, of every kind of clean [in a ritual sense; Lev. 11] animal, and take one pair, each male with its female, of every kind of unclean animal.

1.verse: Nations Grow and Spread - ·This is the family history [These are the generations; 2:4] of Shem, Ham, and Japheth, the sons of Noah. After the flood ·these three men had sons [sons were born to them].

1.verse: Abram and Lot Separate - So Abram, his wife, and Lot ·left [came up from] Egypt, taking everything they owned, and traveled ·to southern Canaan [into the Negev; a somewhat desolate area].

3.verse: He ·left [went by stages from] ·southern Canaan [the Negev] and went back to Bethel where ·he had camped before [his tent had been], between Bethel and Ai [12:8],

1.verse: Lot Is Captured - Now Amraphel was king of ·Babylonia [Shinar], Arioch was king of Ellasar [possibly in Mesopotamia], Kedorlaomer was king of Elam [located on the Iranian plateau], and Tidal was king of Goiim [possibly a people otherwise known as the Umman-manda].

(Bela is also called Zoar.) [Sodom and Gomorrah were located in the vicinity of the Dead Sea, and the other named cities are thought to have been nearby.]

3.verse: These kings who were attacked united their armies in the Valley of Siddim (·now [that is] the ·Dead [Salt] Sea).

4.verse: They had served Kedorlaomer for twelve years, but in the thirteenth year, they all ·turned [rebelled] against him.

5.verse: Then in the fourteenth year, Kedorlaomer and the kings with him came and ·defeated [subdued] the ·Rephaites [or Rephaim; an especially warlike tribe in Canaan] in Ashteroth Karnaim, the Zuzites in Ham, and the Emites in Shaveh Kiriathaim [the Zuzites and Emites were likely related to the Rephaites; Deut. 2:10–11].

6.verse: They also defeated the Horites in the mountains of ·Edom [Seir; a region outside of Palestine on the southeastern coast of the Dead Sea] to El Paran (near the ·desert [wilderness]).

7.verse: Then they turned back and went to En Mishpat (that is, Kadesh). They ·defeated [subdued] all the Amalekites [a fearsome tribe in pre-Israelite Canaan], as well as the Amorites who lived in Hazazon Tamar.

8.verse: At that time the kings of Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, Zeboiim, and Bela went out to fight in the Valley of Siddim. (Bela is called Zoar.)

9.verse: They fought against Kedorlaomer king of Elam, Tidal king of Goiim, Amraphel king of ·Babylonia [Shinar], and Arioch king of Ellasar—four kings fighting against five.

10.verse: There were many ·tar [bitumen] pits in the Valley of Siddim. When the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah and their armies ·ran away [fled], some of the soldiers fell into the tar pits, but the others ·ran away [fled] to the mountains.

11.verse: Now Kedorlaomer and his armies took everything the people of Sodom and Gomorrah owned, including their food, and left.

12.verse: They took Lot, Abram’s ·nephew [son of his brother] who was living in Sodom, and ·everything he owned [his possessions/goods]. Then they left.

13.verse: One of the men who was not captured went to Abram, the Hebrew, and told him what had happened. At that time Abram was camped near the ·great trees [oaks; or terebinths] of Mamre the Amorite. Mamre was a brother of Eshcol and Aner, and they had all made an ·agreement to help [covenant/treaty with] Abram.

14.verse: Abram Rescues Lot - When Abram learned that ·Lot [his relative/brother] had been captured, he called out his 318 trained men who had been born in his camp. He led the men and ·chased the enemy [went in pursuit] all the way to the town of Dan [in the far north of Palestine].

15.verse: That night he divided his men into groups, and ·they made a surprise attack against the enemy [he subdued/defeated/struck them]. They chased them all the way to Hobah, north of Damascus [a major city in Syria].

16.verse: Then Abram brought back ·everything the enemy had stolen [all their possessions/goods], the women and the other people, and Lot, and ·everything Lot owned [his goods/possessions].

17.verse: After defeating Kedorlaomer and the kings who were with him, Abram ·went home [returned]. As he was returning, the king of Sodom came out to meet him in the Valley of Shaveh (now called King’s Valley [somewhere in the vicinity of Jerusalem]).

18.verse: Melchizedek king of ·Salem [probably an old name of Jerusalem] brought out bread and wine. He was a priest for God Most High [Ps. 110; Heb. 5:6–10; 6:20—7:28]

19.verse: and blessed Abram, saying, “Abram, may you be blessed by God Most High, the ·God [one] who made heaven and earth.

20.verse: And ·we praise [blessed be] God Most High, who has ·helped you to defeat your enemies [delivered your enemies into your hand].” Then Abram gave Melchizedek a ·tenth [tithe] of everything he had brought back from the battle.

21.verse: The king of Sodom said to Abram, “You may keep ·all these things [the goods/possessions] for yourself. Just give me my people who were captured.”

22.verse: But Abram said to the king of Sodom, “I ·make a promise [lifted my hand; a gesture of swearing] to the LORD, the God Most High, who made heaven and earth.

23.verse: I promise that I will not keep anything that is yours. I will not keep even a thread or a sandal strap [that is, not the smallest thing] so that you cannot say, ‘I made Abram rich.’

24.verse: I will keep nothing but the food my young men have eaten. But give Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre their share of what we won, because they went with me into battle.”

1.verse: God’s Covenant with Abram - After these things happened, the LORD spoke his word to Abram in a vision: “Abram, don’t be afraid. I will ·defend [be a shield to] you, and ·I will give you a great reward [your reward will be great].”

2.verse: But Abram said, “Lord GOD [Hebrew Adonai Yahweh; combination of covenant name YHWH (2:4) with common Hebrew word for “sir,” “lord,” or “master”], what can you give me? I ·have no son [am childless], so my ·slave [servant] Eliezer from Damascus [a major city in Syria] will ·get everything I own after I die [be my heir; a household servant would take care of a childless couple in their old age and in turn inherit their possessions].”

3.verse: Abram said, “Look, you have given me no son, so a slave born in my house will ·inherit everything I have [be my heir].”

4.verse: Then the LORD spoke his word to Abram: “He will not be the one to inherit what you have. You will have a son of your own who will inherit what you have.”

5.verse: Then God led Abram outside and said, “Look at the ·sky [heavens]. There are so many stars you cannot count them. Your ·descendants [seed] also will be too many to count.”

6.verse: Abram ·believed [put his trust/faith in] the LORD. And the LORD ·accepted Abram’s faith, and that faith made him right with God [counted/credited it as righteousness; Rom. 4:3, 9, 22; Gal. 3:6; James 2:23].

7.verse: God said to Abram, “I am the LORD who led you out of Ur of ·Babylonia [the Chaldeans] so that I could give you this land ·to own [as a possession; 12:1–3].”

8.verse: But Abram said, “Lord GOD, how can I ·be sure [know] that I will ·own this land [possess/inherit it]?”

9.verse: ·The LORD [He] said to Abram, “Bring me a three-year-old cow, a three-year-old goat, a three-year-old ·male sheep [ram], a ·dove [turtledove], and a young pigeon.”

10.verse: Abram brought them all to God. Then Abram ·killed the animals and cut each of them into two pieces [split them down the middle], laying each half opposite the other half. But he did not cut the birds in half.

11.verse: Later, ·large birds [or birds of prey] flew down to eat the ·animals [carcasses], but Abram chased them away [perhaps representing later enemies of Israel].

12.verse: As the sun was ·going down [setting], Abram fell into a deep sleep. While he was asleep, a very ·terrible [or frightening] darkness came.

13.verse: Then the LORD said to Abram, “You can be sure that your ·descendants [seed] will be ·strangers [sojourners; wanderers; resident aliens] in a land they don’t own. The people there will make them slaves and ·be cruel to [oppress] them for four hundred years.

14.verse: But I will ·punish [judge] the nation ·where they are slaves [which they serve]. Then your ·descendants [seed] will leave that land, taking great ·wealth [possessions] with them.

15.verse: And you, Abram, will ·die [go to your fathers/ancestors] in peace and will be buried at an old age.

16.verse: ·After your great-great-grandchildren are born [After the fourth generation], ·your people [they] will come ·to this land [here] again. It will take that long, because ·I am not yet going to punish the Amorites for their evil behavior [the iniquity of the Amorites is not yet complete; Amorites is one name for the pre-Israelite inhabitants of Canaan].”

17.verse: After the sun went down, it was very dark. Suddenly a smoking firepot and a blazing torch [fire and smoke often represent God] passed between the ·halves of the dead animals [pieces; a self-curse ritual; by passing between the pieces of the sacrifice, one vowed to keep an agreement or suffer the same fate as the animals].

18.verse: So on that day the LORD ·made an agreement [cut a covenant/treaty; 6:18] with Abram and said, “I will give to your ·descendants [seed] the land between the river of Egypt and the great river Euphrates.

19.verse: This is the land of the Kenites, Kenizzites, Kadmonites,

20.verse: Hittites, Perizzites, Rephaites,

21.verse: Amorites, Canaanites, Girgashites, and Jebusites [the name of peoples who lived in pre-Israelite Canaan].”

1.verse: Ishmael Is Born - Sarai, Abram’s wife, had no children, but she had a slave girl from Egypt named Hagar.

2.verse: Sarai said to Abram, “Look, the LORD has ·not allowed me to have [prevented/restrained me from having] children, so ·have sexual relations with [go to] my slave girl. If she has a child, maybe I can ·have my own family [reproduce; have a child; build] through her [taking a second wife or concubine was common for a childless couple at the time].” Abram did what Sarai said.

3.verse: It was after he had lived ten years in Canaan that Sarai gave Hagar to her husband Abram as a ·wife [or concubine]. (Hagar was her slave girl from Egypt.)

4.verse: Abram ·had sexual relations with [went in to] Hagar, and she ·became pregnant [conceived]. When Hagar learned she ·was pregnant [conceived], she began to ·treat [look on] her mistress Sarai ·badly [with contempt].

5.verse: Then Sarai said to Abram, “·This is your fault [May the wrong/violence done to me be on you]. I gave my slave girl ·to you [into your embrace; into your lap], and when she ·became pregnant [conceived], she began to ·treat [look on] me ·badly [with contempt]. Let the LORD ·decide who is right—[judge between] you or me.”

6.verse: But Abram said to Sarai, “·You are Hagar’s mistress [Your slave girl is in your hand/power]. Do ·anything you want [what is good in your eyes] to her.” Then Sarai ·was hard on [afflicted; abused] Hagar, and Hagar ·ran away [fled from her presence].

7.verse: The ·angel [messenger] of the LORD [the angel of the Lord was either a representative of the Lord or the Lord himself; v. 13; Judg. 6:11, 14] found Hagar beside a spring of water in the ·desert [wilderness], by the road to Shur [likely a location in southern Canaan; 20:1; 25:18; Ex. 15:22; 1 Sam. 15:7].

8.verse: ·The angel [He] said, “Hagar, Sarai’s slave girl, where have you come from? Where are you going?” Hagar answered, “I am ·running away [fleeing] from my mistress Sarai.”

9.verse: The ·angel [messenger] of the LORD [16:7] said to her, “Go home to your mistress and ·obey [submit to] her.”

10.verse: The angel of the LORD also said, “I will ·give you so many descendants [greatly multiply your seed so that] they cannot be counted.”

11.verse: The ·angel [messenger] added, “You ·are now pregnant [have conceived], and you will ·have [give birth to] a son. You will name him Ishmael [sounds like the verb “to hear”], because the LORD has heard ·your cries [of your affliction].

12.verse: Ishmael will be ·like a wild donkey [a wild donkey/ass of a man]. ·He [His hand] will be against everyone, and ·everyone [everyone’s hand] will be against him. He will ·attack [dwell against] all his brothers.”

13.verse: The slave girl gave a name to the LORD who spoke to her: “You are ‘·God who sees me [or God of seeing; Hebrew El-Roi]’ ” because she said to herself, “Have I really seen God who sees me?”

14.verse: So the well there, between Kadesh [also known as Kadesh Barnea in northeast Sinai] and Bered [location unknown], was called Beer Lahai Roi [the well of the Living One who sees me].

15.verse: Hagar gave birth to a son for Abram, and Abram named ·him [his son which Hagar bore him] Ishmael.

16.verse: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar gave birth to Ishmael.

1.verse: Proof of the Covenant - When Abram was ninety-nine years old, the LORD appeared to him and said, “I am ·God Almighty [El Shaddai]. ·Obey [Walk before] me and ·do what is right [be innocent/blameless; Job 1:1].

2.verse: I will make an ·agreement [covenant; treaty; 6:18] between ·us [me and you], and I will make you ·the ancestor of many people [exceedingly numerous].”

3.verse: Then Abram ·bowed facedown on the ground [fell on his face]. God said to him,

4.verse: “I am making my ·agreement [covenant; treaty; 6:18] with you: I will make you the father of ·many [a host/multitude of] nations.

5.verse: I am changing your name from Abram [meaning “exalted father”] to Abraham [sounds like “father of a multitude” in Hebrew] because I am making you a father of ·many [a host/multitude of] nations.

6.verse: I will ·give you many descendants [cause you to be exceedingly fruitful; 1:22]. ·New nations will be born from you [I will make nations of you], and kings will come from you.

7.verse: And I will make an ·agreement [covenant; treaty; 6:18] between me and you and all your ·descendants [seed] ·from now on [or forever]: I will be your God and the God of all your descendants.

8.verse: You live in the land of Canaan now as a ·stranger [sojourner; wanderer; resident alien], but I will give you and your ·descendants [seed] all this land ·forever [as a permanent possesssion]. And I will be the God of your ·descendants [seed].”

9.verse: Then God said to Abraham, “You and your ·descendants [seed] must ·keep [obey; guard] this ·agreement [covenant; treaty; 6:18] ·from now on [throughout their generations].

10.verse: This is my ·agreement [covenant; treaty; 6:18] with you and all your ·descendants [seed], which you must ·obey [keep; guard]: Every male among you must be circumcised [the ritual of membership in the covenant/treaty].

11.verse: ·Cut away [Circumcise] [the flesh of] your foreskin ·to show that you are prepared to follow the agreement [as a sign of the covenant/treaty] between me and you.

12.verse: ·From now on [Throughout your generations] when a baby boy is eight days old, you will circumcise him. This includes any ·boy born among your people [house-born slave] or any who is ·your slave [bought with money from a foreigner], who is not one of your ·descendants [seed].

13.verse: Circumcise every baby boy whether he is born in your ·family [house] or bought ·as a slave [with money from a foreigner]. ·Your bodies will be marked to show that you are part of my agreement […so that my covenant/treaty might be in your flesh as a covenant/treaty] that lasts forever.

14.verse: Any [uncircumcised] male ·who [whose foreskin] is not circumcised will be cut off from his people, because he has broken my ·agreement [covenant; treaty; 6:18].”

15.verse: Isaac—the Promised Son - God said to Abraham, “I will change the name of Sarai [meaning “princess” in her native dialect; 11:29], your wife, to Sarah [also meaning “princess,” but in a dialect of Canaan, signifying her transition to the Promised Land].

16.verse: I will bless her and give ·her a son, and you will be the father [from her to you a son]. She will ·be the mother of [give rise to] many nations. Kings of nations will come from her.”

17.verse: Abraham ·bowed facedown on the ground [fell on his face] and laughed. He ·said to himself [thought; said in his heart], “Can a man have a child when he is a hundred years old? Can Sarah give birth to a child when she is ninety?”

18.verse: Then Abraham said to God, “Please let Ishmael ·be the son you promised [live before you].”

19.verse: God said, “·No, [or Yes, but] Sarah your wife will have a son, and you will name him Isaac [related to the verb meaning “to laugh”]. I will make my ·agreement [covenant; treaty; 6:18] with him to be an ·agreement that continues forever [eternal covenant/treaty] with all his ·descendants [seed].

20.verse: “As for Ishmael, I have heard you. I will bless him and ·give him many descendants [make him fruitful]. And I will cause their numbers to grow greatly. He will be the father of twelve great ·leaders [princes; chiefs; 25:16], and I will make him into a great nation.

21.verse: But I will make my ·agreement [covenant; treaty; 6:18] with Isaac, the son whom Sarah will have at this same time next year.”

22.verse: After ·God [he] finished talking with Abraham, God ·rose and left him [went up from Abraham].

23.verse: Then Abraham ·gathered [took] Ishmael, all the males ·born in his camp [of his house], and ·the slaves he had bought [those bought with money]. So that day Abraham circumcised [the flesh of his foreskin of] every man and boy in his camp as God had told him to do.

24.verse: Abraham was ninety-nine years old when he ·was circumcised [circumcised the flesh of his foreskin].

25.verse: And Ishmael, his son, was thirteen years old when he was circumcised [in the flesh of his foreskin].

26.verse: Abraham and his son were circumcised on the same day.

27.verse: Also on that day all the men in Abraham’s camp were circumcised, including all those born in his ·camp [house] and all ·the slaves he had bought from other nations [all those bought of a stranger].

1.verse: The Three Visitors - Later, the LORD again appeared to Abraham near the ·great trees [oaks; or terebinths] of Mamre [an area near Hebron, named after Amorite leader; 14:13, 24]. Abraham was sitting at the entrance of his tent ·during the hottest part [in the heat] of the day.

2.verse: He ·looked up [raised his eyes] and saw three men standing near him. When Abraham saw them, he ran from [the entrance of] his tent to meet them. He bowed facedown on the ground before them

3.verse: and said, “·Sir [My lord], if ·you think well of me [I have found grace in your eyes], please ·stay awhile with me, [do not pass by] your servant.

4.verse: I will bring some water so all of you can wash your feet. You may rest under the tree,

5.verse: and I will get some bread for you so you can regain your strength. Then you may ·continue your journey [pass by].” The three men said, “That is fine. Do as you said.” [In the ancient Near East, hospitality towards strangers was a very imporant value.]

6.verse: Abraham hurried to the tent where Sarah was and said to her, “Hurry, ·prepare [take and knead] ·twenty quarts [three seahs] of fine flour, and make ·it into loaves of bread [cakes].”

7.verse: Then Abraham ran to his herd and took one of his ·best [tender and good/choice] calves. He gave it to a servant, who hurried ·to kill it and to prepare it for food [to prepare it].

8.verse: Abraham gave the three men the calf that had been ·cooked [prepared] and milk curds and milk. While they ate, he stood under the tree near them.

9.verse: The men asked Abraham, “Where is your wife Sarah?” “There, in the tent,” said Abraham.

10.verse: Then ·the LORD [he] said, “I will certainly return to you ·about this time a year from now [or in due time; about the living time]. At that time your wife Sarah will have a son.” Sarah was listening at the entrance of the tent which was behind him.

11.verse: Abraham and Sarah were very old. Since ·Sarah was past the age when women normally have children [it had stopped being with Sarah after the manner of women; she had reached menopause],

12.verse: she laughed ·to herself [inwardly], “·My husband and I are too old [I am worn out and my husband is too old] to have ·a baby [pleasure].”

13.verse: Then the LORD said to Abraham, “Why did Sarah laugh? Why did she say, ‘I am too old to have a baby’?

14.verse: Is anything too hard for the LORD? No! I will return to you ·at the right time a year from now [or in due time; about the living time], and Sarah will have a son.”

15.verse: Sarah was afraid, so she ·lied [denied it] and said, “I didn’t laugh.” But the LORD said, “No. You did laugh.”

16.verse: Then the men got up to leave and ·started out [looked] toward Sodom. Abraham walked along with them a short time to send them on their way.

17.verse: Abraham’s Bargain with God - The LORD said, “Should I ·tell [hide from] Abraham what I am going to do now?

18.verse: ·Abraham’s children [Abraham] will certainly become a great and powerful nation, and all nations on earth will be blessed through him [12:1–3].

19.verse: I have ·chosen [known] him so he would command his children and his ·descendants [household] to ·live [keep] the way the LORD wants them to, ·to live right and be fair […by doing righteousness and justice]. Then I, the LORD, will give Abraham what I promised him.”

20.verse: Then the LORD said, “·I have heard many complaints [The outcry is great] against the people of Sodom and Gomorrah [14:2]. ·They are very evil [Their sin is very great/heavy].

21.verse: I will go down and see if they ·are as bad as I have heard [have done according to the outcry which has come to me]. If not, I will know.”

22.verse: So the men turned and went toward Sodom, but Abraham stood there before the LORD.

23.verse: Then Abraham approached him and asked, “Do you plan to ·destroy [sweep away] the ·good people [righteous] along with the ·evil ones [wicked]?

24.verse: What if there are fifty ·good people [righteous] in that city? Will you still ·destroy it [sweep it away]? Surely you will ·save [spare] the ·city [place] for the fifty ·good people [righteous] living there.

25.verse: ·Surely [It would be a desecration for you!] you will not ·destroy [kill; slay] the ·good people [righteous] along with the ·evil ones [wicked]; then they would be treated the same. You are the judge of all the earth. Won’t you do what is ·right [just]?”

26.verse: The LORD said, “If I find fifty ·good people [righteous] in the city of Sodom, I will ·save [spare] the whole ·city [place] because of them.”

27.verse: Then Abraham [answered and] said, “Though I am only dust and ashes, I have been brave to speak to the Lord.

28.verse: What if ·there are only forty-five good people [five of the fifty righteous are lacking] in the city? Will you destroy the whole city for the lack of five ·good people [righteous]?” The LORD said, “If I find forty-five there, I will not destroy the city.”

29.verse: Again Abraham said to him, “If you find only forty ·good people [righteous] there, will you destroy the city?” The LORD said, “If I find forty, I will not destroy it.”

30.verse: Then Abraham said, “Lord, please don’t be angry with me, but let me ask you this. If you find only thirty ·good people [righteous] in the city, will you destroy it?” He said, “If I find thirty ·good people [righteous] there, I will not destroy the city.”

31.verse: Then Abraham said, “I have been brave to speak to the Lord. But what if there are twenty ·good people [righteous] in the city?” He answered, “If I find twenty there, I will not destroy the city.”

32.verse: Then Abraham said, “Lord, please don’t be angry with me, but let me bother you this one last time. What if you find ten there?” He said, “If I find ten there, I will not destroy it.”

33.verse: When the LORD finished speaking to Abraham, he left, and Abraham returned ·home [to his place].

1.verse: Lot Leaves Sodom - The two ·angels [messengers] came to Sodom in the evening as Lot was sitting near the ·city gate [gate of Sodom; the administrative center of a city]. When he saw them, he got up ·and went to [to meet] them and bowed facedown on the ground.

2.verse: Lot said, “·Sirs [My lords], please come to ·my [your servant’s] house and spend the night. There you can wash your feet, and then ·tomorrow you may [you can get up early and] continue your journey.” The ·angels [messengers] answered, “No, we will spend the night in the city’s public square.”

3.verse: But Lot ·begged them [entreated/urged them strongly] to come, so they ·agreed [turned aside to him] and went to his house. Then Lot prepared a ·meal [feast; banquet] for them. He baked ·bread without yeast [unleavened bread], and they ate it.

4.verse: Before ·bedtime [they lay down], men both young and old and from every part of Sodom surrounded Lot’s house.

5.verse: They called to Lot, “Where are the two men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us so we can ·have sexual relations with [know] them.”

6.verse: Lot went ·outside [out the door] to them, closing the door behind him.

7.verse: He said, “No, my brothers! Do not do this evil thing.

8.verse: Look! I have two daughters who have never ·slept with [had sexual relations with; known] a man. I will give them to you, and you may do anything you want with them. But please don’t do anything to these men. They have come ·to my house, and I must protect them [under the shelter/shade of my roof].”

9.verse: The men around the house answered, “·Move out of the way [Stand back]!” Then they said to each other, “This ·man Lot [fellow; one] came to our city as a ·stranger [sojourner; wanderer; resident alien], and now he wants to ·tell us what to do [judge us]!” They said to Lot, “We will do worse things to you than to them.” They started pushing him back and were ready to break down the door.

10.verse: But ·the two men staying with Lot [the men] ·opened the door, [reached out their hands and] pulled him back inside the house, and then closed the door.

11.verse: They struck those outside the door with ·blindness [a blinding flash], so the men, both ·young and old [small and great], could not find the door.

12.verse: The two men said to Lot, “Do you have ·any other relatives in this city [anyone else here]? Do you have any sons-in-law, sons, daughters, or any other relatives? If you do, ·tell them to leave now [get them out of this place],

13.verse: because we are about to destroy this ·city [place]. ·The LORD has heard of all the evil that is here [Great is the outcry against them before the LORD], so he has sent us to destroy it.”

14.verse: So Lot went out and said to his future sons-in-law who were pledged to marry his daughters, “·Hurry and leave this city [Get up and get out of this place]! The LORD is about to destroy it!” But ·they [his sons-in-law] thought Lot was joking.

15.verse: ·At dawn the next morning [As morning dawned], the ·angels [messengers] ·begged [urged] Lot to hurry. They said, “Go! Take your wife and your two daughters with you so you will not be ·destroyed [swept away] when the city is punished.”

16.verse: But Lot ·delayed [lingered; dawdled]. So the two men ·took [grabbed; seized] the hands of Lot, his wife, and his two daughters and led them safely out of the city. So the LORD was merciful to Lot and his family.

17.verse: After they brought them out of the city, one of the men said, “·Run [Flee] for your lives! Don’t look back or stop anywhere in the ·valley [or plain]. Run to the mountains, or you will be ·destroyed [swept away].”

18.verse: But Lot said to one of them, “·Sir, please don’t force me to go so far [Oh no, my lord]!

19.verse: ·You have been merciful [Your servant has found grace in your eyes] and ·kind to me [you have shown great kindness to me] and have saved my life. But I can’t ·run [flee] to the mountains. The disaster will catch me, and I will die.

20.verse: Look, that little town over there is ·not too far away [near enough to flee to]. Let me run there. It’s really just a little town, and ·I’ll be safe there [my life will be saved/spared].”

21.verse: The angel said to Lot, “Very well, I will ·allow you to do this also [show you this favor; lift up your face]. I will not ·destroy that town [overthrow the town of which you speak].

22.verse: But run there fast, because I cannot ·destroy Sodom [do anything] until you are safely in that town.” (That town is named Zoar, because it is little [Zoar sounds like the Hebrew word for “little”].)

23.verse: Sodom and Gomorrah Are Destroyed - The sun had already ·come up [risen over the earth] when Lot entered Zoar.

24.verse: The LORD sent a rain of ·burning sulfur [sulfur and fire] down from ·the sky [heaven] on Sodom and Gomorrah

25.verse: and ·destroyed [overturned] those cities. He also ·destroyed [overturned] the whole ·Jordan Valley [valley; or plain], everyone living in the cities, and even all the plants.

26.verse: At that point Lot’s wife looked back. When she did, she became a pillar of salt.

27.verse: Early the next morning, Abraham got up and went to the place where he had stood before the LORD.

28.verse: He looked down toward Sodom and Gomorrah and all the ·Jordan Valley [valley; or plain] and saw smoke rising from the land, like smoke from a furnace.

29.verse: God destroyed the cities in the ·valley [or plain], but he remembered what Abraham had asked. So ·God saved Lot’s life, but he [he sent Lot out of the overthrow/upheaval when he] ·destroyed [overturned] the city where Lot had lived [Deut. 29:23; Is. 1:9; 13:19; Jer. 50:40; Amos 4:11; Matt. 10:15; 11:23–24; Jude 1:7; Rev. 11:8].

30.verse: Lot and His Daughters - Lot was afraid to continue living in Zoar, so he and his two daughters went to live in the mountains in a cave.

31.verse: One day the ·older daughter [firstborn] said to the younger, “Our father is old. ·Everywhere on the earth women and men marry, but there are no men around here for us to marry [There is no man on earth to come into us according to the way of all the earth].

32.verse: Let’s get our father ·drunk [to drink wine] and ·have sexual relations [we will lie] with him. ·We can use him to have children and continue our family […so we may preserve offspring/seed through our father].”

33.verse: That night the two girls ·got their father drunk [made their father drink wine], and the ·older daughter [firstborn] went and ·had sexual relations [lay] with him. But Lot did not know when she lay down or when she got up.

34.verse: The next day the ·older daughter [firstborn] said to the younger, “Last night I ·had sexual relations [lay] with my father. Let’s get him ·drunk [to drink wine] again tonight so you can go and ·have sexual relations [lay] with him, too. In this way we can ·use our father to have children to continue our family [preserve offspring/seed through our father].”

35.verse: So that night they got their father ·drunk [to drink wine] again, and the younger daughter went and ·had sexual relations [lay] with him. Again, Lot did not know when she lay down or when she got up.

36.verse: So both of Lot’s daughters ·became pregnant [conceived] by their father.

37.verse: The older daughter gave birth to a son and named him Moab. He is the ancestor of all the Moabite people who are still living today [located to the east of the Dead Sea in what is today Jordan; the name sounds like “from the father” in Hebrew].

38.verse: The younger daughter also gave birth to a son and named him Ben-Ammi [sounds like “son of my relative” in Hebrew]. He is the father of all the Ammonite people [located just north of Moab; Moab and Ammon were enemies of Israel] who are still living today [at the time this was written].

1.verse: Abraham Tricks Abimelech - Abraham left Hebron [13:18] and traveled to ·southern Canaan [the Negev; 13:1] where he stayed awhile between Kadesh [16:14] and Shur [16:7]. When he ·moved to [sojourned/lived as an alien in] Gerar [north of Kadesh and Shur; present-day Tell Abu Hureirah],

2.verse: he said to people about Sarah his wife, “She is my sister” [12:10–20; 26:1–11]. Abimelech king of Gerar heard this, so he sent some servants to take her.

3.verse: But one night God spoke to Abimelech in a dream and said, “You will die. The woman you took is married.”

4.verse: But Abimelech had not gone near Sarah, so he said, “Lord, would you ·destroy [kill; slay] an innocent nation?

5.verse: ·Abraham himself told [Did he not tell…?] me, ‘This woman is my sister,’ and ·she also said [did she not also say…?], ‘He is my brother.’ I ·am innocent and did not know I was doing anything wrong [did this with a pure conscience/blameless heart and innocent hands].”

6.verse: Then God said to Abimelech in the dream, “Yes, I know you did ·not realize what you were doing [this with a pure conscience/blameless heart]. So I ·did not allow you to sin [restrained you from sinning] against me and touch her.

7.verse: Give ·Abraham [the man] his wife back. He is a prophet [one who interceded for others]. He will pray for you, and you will not die. But if you do not give Sarah back, you and all ·your family [who belong to you] will surely die.”

8.verse: So early the next morning, Abimelech called all his ·officers [servants] and told them everything that had happened in the dream. They were very afraid.

9.verse: Then Abimelech called Abraham to him and said, “What have you done to us? What ·wrong [offense; sin] did I do against you? Why did you bring this ·trouble [great offense/guilt; great sin] to my kingdom? You should not have done these things to me.

10.verse: What ·were you thinking [possessed you] that caused you to do this?”

11.verse: Then Abraham answered, “I thought no one in this place ·respected [feared] God and that someone would kill me to get ·Sarah [my wife].

12.verse: And it is true that she is my sister. She is the daughter of my father, but she is not the daughter of my mother, and she became my wife.

13.verse: When God ·told me to leave my father’s house and wander in many different places [caused me to wander from my father’s home; 12:1], I told Sarah, ‘You must ·do a special favor for [or show loyalty to] me. Everywhere we go tell people, “He is my brother.”’”

14.verse: Then Abimelech gave Abraham some sheep, cattle, and male and female slaves. He also gave Sarah, Abraham’s wife, back to him

15.verse: and said, “·Look around you at my land [My land is before you]. You may live anywhere you want.”

16.verse: Abimelech said to Sarah, “I gave your brother Abraham ·twenty-five pounds [one thousand pieces] of silver ·to make up for any wrong that people may think about you [—a covering of the eyes to all who are with you; an indication that nothing improper happened]. I want everyone to know that you are innocent.”

17.verse: Then Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelech, his wife, and his servant girls so they could have children.

18.verse: The LORD had ·kept all the women in Abimelech’s house from having children [closed up every womb of the house of Abimelech] ·as a punishment on Abimelech for taking [on account of] Abraham’s wife Sarah.

1.verse: A Baby for Sarah - The LORD ·cared for [visited] Sarah as he had said and did for her what he had promised.

2.verse: Sarah ·became pregnant [conceived] and gave birth to a son for Abraham in his old age. Everything happened at the time God had said it would.

3.verse: Abraham named his son Isaac, the son Sarah gave birth to.

4.verse: He circumcised [17:10] Isaac when he was eight days old as God had commanded.

5.verse: Abraham was one hundred years old when his son Isaac was born.

6.verse: And Sarah said, “God has made me laugh [the name Isaac is related to a Hebrew word meaning “laugh”]. Everyone who hears about this will laugh ·with [or at] me.

7.verse: No one thought that I would ·be able to have Abraham’s child [suckle/nurse children], but even though Abraham is old I have given him a son.”

8.verse: Hagar and Ishmael Leave - Isaac grew, and when he ·became old enough to eat food [was weaned], Abraham gave a great feast [on the day of his weaning].

9.verse: But Sarah saw ·Ishmael [the son of Hagar the Egyptian] ·making fun of Isaac [laughing; or playing].

10.verse: So Sarah said to Abraham, “·Throw [Drive] out this slave woman and her son. Her son should not inherit anything; my son Isaac should receive it all [Gal. 4:21—5:1].”

11.verse: This ·troubled [distressed; upset] Abraham very much because Ishmael was also his son.

12.verse: But God said to Abraham, “Don’t be ·troubled [distressed; upset] about the boy and the slave woman. Do ·whatever [all] Sarah tells you. ·The descendants I promised you will be from [The seed will be named for you through] Isaac.

13.verse: I will also make the ·descendants of Ishmael [the son of your slave woman] into a great nation because he is your ·son [seed], too.”

14.verse: Early the next morning Abraham [got up and] took some food and a ·leather bag full [skin] of water. He gave them to Hagar and sent her away. Carrying these things and her son [on her shoulder], Hagar went and wandered [the verb may imply moving aimlessly and without hope] in the ·desert [wilderness] of Beersheba [an area in the northern part of the Negev, southern Canaan].

15.verse: Later, when all the water was ·gone [finished] from the ·bag [skin], Hagar put her son under a bush.

16.verse: Then she went a good way off, the distance of a bowshot, and sat down across from him. She thought, “My son will die, and I cannot watch this happen.” She sat there across from him and began to cry.

17.verse: God heard the ·boy crying [sound/voice of the boy], and God’s ·angel [messenger; 16:7] called to Hagar from heaven. He said, “What is wrong, Hagar? Don’t be afraid! God has heard the ·boy crying [the sound/voice of the boy] there.

18.verse: ·Help [Get up and lift] him up and take him by the hand. I will make ·his descendants [him] into a great nation.” [Ishmael is considered the ancestor of the Arab people.]

19.verse: Then God [opened her eyes and] showed Hagar a well of water. So she went to the well and filled her ·bag [skin] with water and gave the boy a drink.

20.verse: God was with the boy as he grew up. Ishmael lived in the ·desert [wilderness] and became an archer.

21.verse: He lived in the Desert of Paran [a region in the eastern Sinai peninsula], and his mother found a wife for him in Egypt [Hagar’s original homeland].

22.verse: Abraham’s Bargain with Abimelech - ·Then [At that time] Abimelech came with Phicol, the commander of his army, and said to Abraham, “God is with you in everything you do.

23.verse: So ·make a promise to me here before [swear to me by] God that you will ·be fair [not deal falsely] with me and my children and my descendants. Be ·kind [loyal] to me and to this land where you have lived as a ·stranger [sojourner; wanderer; resident alien]—as ·kind [loyal] as I have been to you.”

24.verse: And Abraham said, “I ·promise [swear].”

25.verse: Then Abraham ·complained to [reproved; reproached] Abimelech about Abimelech’s servants who had seized a well of water.

26.verse: But Abimelech said, “I don’t know who did this. You never told me [and I have not heard] about this before today.”

27.verse: Then Abraham gave Abimelech some sheep and cattle, and they made an ·agreement [covenant; treaty].

28.verse: Abraham also put seven female lambs ·in front of Abimelech [apart by themselves].

29.verse: Abimelech asked Abraham, “Why did you put these seven female lambs by themselves?”

30.verse: Abraham answered, “Accept these lambs from ·me [my hand] to ·prove that you believe [verify/witness that] I dug this well.”

31.verse: So that place was called Beersheba [21:14; meaning either “well of seven” or “well of promise”] because they ·made a promise to each other [swore an oath] there.

32.verse: After Abraham and Abimelech ·made the agreement [cut a covenant/treaty] at Beersheba, Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, went back to the land of the Philistines [a region on the southern Mediterranean coast of Canaan].

33.verse: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree at Beersheba and prayed to the LORD, the ·God who lives forever [eternal God].

34.verse: And Abraham lived as a ·stranger [wanderer; sojourner; resident alien] in the land of the Philistines for ·a long time [many days].

1.verse: God Tests Abraham - After these things God tested ·Abraham’s faith [Abraham]. God said to him, “Abraham!” And he answered, “Here I am.”

2.verse: Then God said, “Take your ·only [or precious] son, Isaac, the son you love, and go to the land of Moriah [2 Chr. 3:1; the temple would later be built here]. Offer him as a whole burnt offering on one of the mountains I will tell you about.”

3.verse: Abraham got up early in the morning and saddled his donkey. He took Isaac and two ·servants [or young men] with him. After he cut the wood for the sacrifice, they went to the place God had told them to go.

4.verse: On the third day Abraham ·looked up [lifted his eyes] and saw the place in the distance.

5.verse: He said to his ·servants [or young men], “Stay here with the donkey. My son and I will go over there and worship, and then we will come back to you.”

6.verse: Abraham took the wood for the ·sacrifice [whole burnt offering] and ·gave it to his son to carry [placed it on his son], but he himself took the knife and the ·fire [or tinder]. So he and his son went on together.

7.verse: Isaac said to his father Abraham, “Father!” Abraham answered, “Yes, my son.” Isaac said, “We have the ·fire [or tinder] and the wood, but where is the ·lamb [sheep] ·we will burn as a sacrifice [for the whole burnt offering]?”

8.verse: Abraham answered, “God will ·give us [provide; see for] the ·lamb [sheep] for the ·sacrifice [whole burnt offering], my son.” So Abraham and his son went on together

9.verse: and came to the place God had told him about. Abraham built an altar there. He ·laid [arranged] the wood on it and then ·tied up [bound] his son Isaac and laid him on the wood on the altar.

10.verse: Then Abraham [sent his hand and] took his knife and was about to ·kill [slaughter] his son.

11.verse: But the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD [16:7] called to him from heaven and said, “Abraham! Abraham!” Abraham answered, “Yes.”

12.verse: The angel said, “Don’t ·kill [send out your hand against] your son or ·hurt [do anything to] him in any way. Now I can see that you ·trust [fear] God and that you have not ·kept [withheld] your son, your ·only [or precious] son, from me [Heb. 11:17–19; James 2:21–23].”

13.verse: Then Abraham ·looked up [lifted his eyes] and saw ·a [or another] ·male sheep [ram] caught in a ·bush [thicket] by its horns. So Abraham went and took the sheep offering it as a whole burnt offering to God, ·and his son was saved [ … in the place of his son].

14.verse: So Abraham named that place The LORD ·Provides [or Sees; Hebrew: Yahweh Yireh]. Even today people say, “On the mountain of the LORD it will be ·provided [or seen].”

15.verse: The ·angel [messenger] of the LORD [16:7] called to Abraham from heaven a second time

16.verse: and said, “The LORD says, ‘Because you did not ·keep back [withhold] your son, your ·only [precious] son, from me, I ·make you this promise by my own name [swear by myself]:

17.verse: I will surely bless you and ·give you many descendants [multiply your seed]. They will be as many as the stars in the ·sky [heavens] and the sand on the seashore, and they will ·capture [possess] the ·cities [gates] of their enemies.

18.verse: Through your ·descendants [seed] all the nations on the earth will be blessed, because you ·obeyed [listened to] me [12:1–3].’ ”

19.verse: Then Abraham returned to his ·servants [young men]. They all traveled back to Beersheba, and Abraham ·stayed there [resided in Beersheba; 21:14].

20.verse: After these things happened, someone told Abraham: “·Your brother Nahor and his wife Milcah have children now [Milcah has born sons to Nahor your brother; 11:29].

21.verse: The ·first son [firstborn] is Uz, and ·the second [his brother] is Buz. ·The third son is […and] Kemuel (the father of Aram).

22.verse: Then there are Kesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.”

23.verse: Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. Milcah was the mother of these eight sons, and Nahor, Abraham’s brother, was the father.

24.verse: Also Nahor had four other sons by his ·slave woman [concubine; a secondary wife] Reumah. Their names were Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah [Nahor’s offspring may have been the ancestors of the Aramaean tribes in Syria].

1.verse: Sarah Dies - Sarah lived to be one hundred twenty-seven years old [such were the years of Sarah’s life].

2.verse: She died in Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron [city nineteen miles south of Jerusalem]) in the land of Canaan. Abraham ·was very sad [mourned] and cried because of her.

3.verse: After a while he got up from the side of his ·wife’s body [dead] and went to talk to the Hittites [one of the many groups that made up the population of Canaan at the time, notable in that they were not Semitic as the others were]. He said,

4.verse: “I am only a ·stranger [sojourner; wanderer; resident alien] and a ·foreigner [settler; the combination of terms indicates a resident alien] here. Sell me some ·of your land [property for a burial place] so that I can bury my ·dead wife [dead].”

5.verse: The Hittites answered Abraham,

6.verse: “·Sir [My lord], you are a ·great leader [mighty prince; or prince of God; a man of wealth and power even though he owned no land] among us. You may have the ·best [choicest] place we have to bury your dead. You may have any of our burying places that you want, and none of us will stop you from burying your ·dead wife [dead].”

7.verse: Abraham rose and bowed to the people of the land, the Hittites.

8.verse: He said to them, “If you truly ·want to help me [are willing for me to] bury my ·dead wife [dead] here, ·speak to [entreat] Ephron, the son of Zohar for me.

9.verse: Ask him to sell me the cave of Machpelah at the edge of his field. I will pay him the full price. You can be the witnesses that I am buying it as a burial place.”

10.verse: Ephron was sitting among the Hittites at the city gate [place where commercial transactions took place]. He answered Abraham [in the hearing of the Hittites],

11.verse: “No, ·sir [my Lord]. [Hear me,] I will give you the ·land [field] and the cave that is in it, with these people as witnesses. Bury your ·dead wife [dead].”

12.verse: Then Abraham bowed down before the ·Hittites [people of the land].

13.verse: He said to Ephron ·before [in the hearing of] all the people, “·Please let me [Listen to me. I will] pay you the full price for the field. Accept my money, and I will bury my dead there.”

14.verse: Ephron answered Abraham,

15.verse: “·Sir [My Lord], [Listen to me,] the land is worth ·ten pounds [400 shekels] of silver, ·but I won’t argue with you over the price [what is that between you and me?]. Take the land, and bury your ·dead wife [dead].”

16.verse: Abraham ·agreed [listened] and paid Ephron in front of the Hittite witnesses. He weighed out the full price, ·ten pounds [400 shekels] of silver, and they counted the weight as the traders normally did.

17.verse: So Ephron’s field in Machpelah, east of Mamre, was sold. Abraham became the owner of the field, the cave in it, and all the trees that were in the field. The sale was made at the city gate, with the Hittites as witnesses [the first land actually owned by Abraham].

18.verse: So Ephron’s field in Machpelah, east of Mamre, was sold. Abraham became the owner of the field, the cave in it, and all the trees that were in the field. The sale was made at the city gate, with the Hittites as witnesses [the first land actually owned by Abraham].

19.verse: After this, Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre. (Mamre was later called Hebron in the land of Canaan.)

20.verse: So Abraham bought the field and the cave in it from the Hittites to use as a burying place.

1.verse: A Wife for Isaac - Abraham was now very old, ·along in years [going in days], and the LORD had blessed him in every way.

2.verse: Abraham said to his oldest servant [in his house], who was in charge of everything he owned, “Put your hand under my ·leg [thigh; a euphemism for male genitalia, expressing commitment to keep a promise].

3.verse: ·Make a promise to me before [Swear to me by] the LORD, the God of heaven and [the God of] earth. Don’t get a wife for my son from the ·Canaanite girls [daughters of the Canaanites] who live around here.

4.verse: Instead, go back to my country, to the land of my relatives, and get a wife for my son Isaac.”

5.verse: The servant said to him, “·What if [Perhaps] this woman does not want to return with me to this land? Then, should I take your son with me back to your homeland?”

6.verse: Abraham said to him, “No! ·Don’t take [Be careful not to take] my son back there.

7.verse: The LORD, the God of heaven, brought me from the home of my father and the land of my relatives. And he ·promised [swore to] me, ‘I will give this land to your ·descendants [seed].’ The LORD will send his ·angel [messenger] before you to help you get a wife for my son there.

8.verse: If the ·girl [woman] won’t come back with you, you will be ·free [declared innocent] from this promise. But you must not take my son back there.”

9.verse: So the servant put his hand under his master’s ·leg [thigh; 24:2] and ·made a promise [swore] to Abraham about this.

10.verse: The servant took ten of Abraham’s camels and left, carrying with him many ·different kinds of beautiful gifts [goods of his master]. He went to ·northwestern Mesopotamia [Aram-Naharaim; a region near the Habor and Euphrates rivers, about a month’s journey away] to ·Nahor’s city [or the city of Nahor].

11.verse: In the evening, when the women come out to get water [most ancient towns had a single source of water for the community], he made the camels kneel down at the well outside the city.

12.verse: The servant said, “LORD, God of my master Abraham, ·allow me to find a wife for his son [grant me good fortune] today. Please show this ·kindness [loyalty] to my master Abraham.

13.verse: Here I am, standing by the spring, and the ·girls [daughters of the men] from the city are coming out to get water.

14.verse: ·I will say to one of them [Let the girl to whom I will say…], ‘Please put your jar down so I can drink.’ Then let her say, ‘Drink, and I will also give water to your camels.’ If that happens, I will know she is the ·right one [the one appointed/selected] for your servant Isaac and that you have shown ·kindness [loyalty] to my master.”

15.verse: Before the servant had finished ·praying [speaking], Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel, came out of the city. (Bethuel was the son of Milcah and Nahor, Abraham’s brother [11:27–30].) Rebekah was carrying her water jar on her shoulder.

16.verse: She was ·very pretty [extremely beautiful], a virgin; she had never ·had sexual relations with [known] a man. She went down to the spring and filled her jar, then came back up.

17.verse: The servant ran to her and said, “Please give me a little ·water [sip] from your jar.”

18.verse: Rebekah said, “Drink, ·sir [my master].” She quickly lowered the jar ·from her shoulder [on her hand] and gave him a drink.

19.verse: After ·he finished drinking [she let him drink all he wanted], Rebekah said, “I will also pour some water for your camels [until they have finished drinking].”
