20.verse: So she quickly ·poured [emptied] all the water from her jar into the drinking trough for the camels. Then she kept running to the well until she had given all the camels enough to drink.

21.verse: The ·servant [man] quietly ·watched [stared at] her. He wanted to ·be sure [learn whether or not] the LORD had made his trip successful.

22.verse: After the camels had finished drinking, he gave Rebekah a gold ·ring [nose-ring; or earring] weighing ·one-fifth of an ounce [one half shekel] and two gold arm bracelets weighing about ·four ounces [ten shekels] each.

23.verse: He asked, “·Who is your father [Tell me whose daughter you are]? Is there a place in his house for me and my men to spend the night?”

24.verse: Rebekah answered, “·My father is [The daughter of] Bethuel, the son of Milcah and Nahor.”

25.verse: Then she said, “And, yes, we have ·straw for your camels [plenty of straw and feed] and a place for you to spend the night.”

26.verse: The servant bowed and worshiped the LORD

27.verse: and said, “Blessed is the LORD, the God of my master Abraham. The LORD ·has been kind and truthful to him [has not abandoned his kindness/loyalty and truthfulness/faithfulness to my master] and has led me to my master’s relatives.”

28.verse: Then Rebekah ran and told her mother’s family about all these things.

29.verse: She had a brother named Laban, who ran out to Abraham’s servant, who was still at the spring.

30.verse: Laban had heard what she had said and had seen the ·ring [nose-ring; or earring] and the bracelets on his sister’s arms. So he ran out to the well, and there was the man standing by the camels at the spring.

31.verse: Laban said, “·Sir [O blessed one], ·you are welcome to come in [come]; ·you don’t have to stand [why are standing…?] outside. I have ·prepared [cleared out] the house for you and also a place for your camels.”

32.verse: So Abraham’s servant went into the house. After Laban unloaded the camels and gave them straw and ·food [fodder], he gave water to Abraham’s servant so he and the men with him could wash their feet.

33.verse: Then ·Laban gave the servant food [the food was set before him], but the servant said, “I will not eat until I have told you why I came.” So Laban said, “Then tell us.”

35.verse: The LORD has greatly blessed my master in everything [12:3], and he has become a rich man. The LORD has given him many flocks of sheep, herds of cattle, silver and gold, male and female servants, camels, and horses.

36.verse: Sarah, my master’s wife, gave birth to a son when she was old [21:1–7], and my master has given everything he owns to that son.

37.verse: My master had me ·make a promise to him [swear] and said, ‘Don’t get a wife for my son from the Canaanite ·girls [daughters] ·who live around here [in whose land I live].

38.verse: Instead, you must go to my father’s ·people [house] and to my family. There you must ·get [take] a wife for my son.’

39.verse: I said to my master, ‘What if the woman will not come back with me?’

40.verse: But he said, ‘I ·serve [walk before] the LORD, who will send his ·angel [or messenger] with you and will ·help you [make your way successful]. You will ·get [take] a wife for my son from my family and my father’s ·people [house].

41.verse: Then you will be ·free [innocent] from ·the promise [my oath]. But if they will not give you a wife for my son, you will be ·free [innocent] from ·this promise [my oath].’

42.verse: “Today I came to this spring. I said, ‘LORD, God of my master Abraham, please make my ·trip [way] successful.

43.verse: I am standing by this spring. I will wait for a young woman to come out to ·get [draw] water, and I will say, “Please give me water from your jar to drink.”

44.verse: Then let her say, “Drink this water, and I will also draw water for your camels.” By this I will know the LORD has chosen her for my master’s son.’

45.verse: “Before I finished ·my silent prayer [speaking in my heart/mind], Rebekah came out of the city with her water jar on her shoulder. She went down to the spring and drew water. I said to her, ‘Please give me a drink.’

46.verse: She quickly lowered the jar from her shoulder and said, ‘Drink this. I will also water your camels.’ So I drank, and she watered my camels too.

47.verse: When I asked her, ‘·Who is your father [Whose daughter are you]?’ she answered, ‘·My father is [The daughter of] Bethuel son of Milcah and Nahor.’ Then I put the ring in her nose and the bracelets on her arms,

48.verse: and I bowed my head and ·thanked [worshipped] the LORD. I ·praised [blessed] the LORD, the God of my master Abraham, because he ·led [guided] me on the right road to get the granddaughter of my master’s brother for his son.

49.verse: Now, tell me, will you be ·kind [loyal] and ·truthful [faithful] to my master? And if not, tell me so. Then I will ·know what I should do [turn to the right hand or to the left].”

50.verse: Laban and Bethuel answered, “This ·is clearly [has come out] from the LORD, and we cannot ·change what must happen [speak to you good or evil].

51.verse: Rebekah is ·yours [before you]. Take her and go. Let her marry your master’s son as the LORD has ·commanded [spoken].”

52.verse: When Abraham’s servant heard these words, he bowed facedown on the ground before the LORD.

53.verse: Then he gave Rebekah gold and silver jewelry and clothes. He also gave expensive gifts to her brother and mother.

54.verse: The servant and the men with him ate and drank and spent the night there. When they got up the next morning, the servant said, “·Now let me go [Send me] back to my master.”

55.verse: Rebekah’s mother and her brother said, “Let ·Rebekah [the girl] stay with us at least ten days. After that she may go.”

56.verse: But the servant said to them, “Do not ·make me wait [delay/hinder], because the LORD has made my ·trip [way] successful. Now ·let me go [send me] back to my master.”

57.verse: Rebekah’s brother and mother said, “We will call Rebekah and ask her ·what she wants to do [at her mouth].”

58.verse: They called her and asked her, “Do you want to go with this man now?” She said, “·Yes, I do [I will go].”

59.verse: So they ·allowed Rebekah and her nurse to go [sent Rebekah their sister and her nurse] with Abraham’s servant and his men.

60.verse: They blessed Rebekah and said, “Our sister, may you ·be the mother of thousands of people [thousands of myriads], and may your ·descendants [seed] ·capture [inherit; possess] the ·cities of their enemies [gates of those who hate us].”

61.verse: Then Rebekah and her servant girls ·got on [rose up and mounted] the camels and followed the servant and his men. So the servant took Rebekah and left.

62.verse: At this time Isaac had left Beer Lahai Roi [16:14] and was living in ·southern Canaan [Negev].

63.verse: One evening when he went out to the field to ·think [meditate; reflect; or walk], he ·looked up [raised his eyes] and saw camels coming.

64.verse: Rebekah also ·looked [raised her eyes] and saw Isaac. Then she ·jumped down [fell] from the camel

65.verse: and asked the servant, “Who is that man walking in the field to meet us?” The servant answered, “That is my master.” So Rebekah covered her face with her veil.

66.verse: The servant told Isaac everything that had happened.

67.verse: Then Isaac brought Rebekah into the tent of Sarah, his mother, and she became his wife. Isaac loved her very much, and so he was comforted after his mother’s death.

1.verse: Abraham’s Family - Abraham married again, and his new wife was Keturah [1 Chr. 1:32].

2.verse: She gave birth to Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian [ancestor of the Midianites, the tribe into which Moses married; Ex. 3:1], Ishbak, and Shuah [ancestor of the tribe of Job’s friend Bildad; Job 2:11].

3.verse: Jokshan was the father of Sheba and Dedan [Is. 21:13; Jer. 49:8; Ezek. 27:20]. Dedan’s descendants were the people of Assyria, Letush, and Leum.

4.verse: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were descendants of Keturah.

5.verse: Abraham ·left [gave] everything he owned to Isaac.

6.verse: But ·before Abraham died [while he was still alive], he did give gifts to the sons of his ·other wives [concubines], then sent them to the East to be away from Isaac [to prevent rivalry over Abraham’s inheritance].

7.verse: ·Abraham lived to be [These are the days of the years of the life of Abraham] one hundred seventy-five years old.

8.verse: He ·breathed his last breath [expired] and died at an old age, ·after a long and satisfying life [an old man and full of years; he was gathered to his people/relatives; buried in the family plot, though may imply joining his ancestors in the afterlife].

9.verse: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah in the field of Ephron east of Mamre. (Ephron was the son of Zohar the Hittite.)

10.verse: So Abraham was buried with his wife Sarah in the same field that he had bought from the Hittites [23:1–20].

11.verse: After Abraham died, God blessed his son Isaac. Isaac was now living at Beer Lahai Roi [16:14].

12.verse: ·This is the family history [These are the generations; 2:4] of Ishmael, Abraham’s son. (Hagar, Sarah’s Egyptian servant, ·was Ishmael’s mother [bore him to Abraham].)

13.verse: These are the names of Ishmael’s sons in the order they were born: Nebaioth, the ·first son [firstborn], then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,

14.verse: Mishma, Dumah, Massa,

15.verse: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.

16.verse: These were Ishmael’s sons, and these are the names of the ·tribal leaders [twelve princes/chieftains according to their tribes; 17:20] listed according to their ·settlements [villages] and camps.

17.verse: ·Ishmael lived [These are the years of the life of Ishmael] one hundred thirty-seven years and then ·breathed his last breath [expired] and died [and was gathered to his people/relatives; 25:8].

18.verse: His descendants lived from Havilah to Shur, which is east of Egypt stretching toward Assyria [the area from the northern Sinai to the border of western Mesopotamia, the area of Arab tribes]. They often ·attacked [or settled among; fell on] the descendants of his brothers.

19.verse: Isaac’s Family - ·This is the family history [These are the generations; 2:4] of Isaac. Abraham ·had a son named [or was the father of] Isaac.

20.verse: When Isaac was forty years old, he ·married [took as a wife] Rebekah [ch. 24], ·who came from northwestern Mesopotamia [the Aramean from Paddan-aram]. She was Bethuel’s daughter and the sister of Laban the Aramean.

21.verse: Isaac’s wife ·could not have children [was barren], so Isaac ·prayed to [entreated; interceded with] the LORD for her. The LORD heard Isaac’s prayer, and Rebekah ·became pregnant [conceived].

22.verse: While she was pregnant, the ·babies [children] struggled inside her. She asked, “·Why is this happening to me [If thus, why this, I—; the Hebrew is uncertain]?” Then she went to ·get an answer from [seek; inquire of] the LORD.

23.verse: The LORD said to her, “Two nations are in your ·body [womb], and two groups of people ·will be taken from you [are being divided within your body]. One group will be stronger than the other, and the older will serve the younger [Rom. 9:10–13].”

24.verse: When the time came, ·Rebekah gave birth to twins [there were twins in her womb].

25.verse: The first baby ·was born [came out] red. Since his skin was like a hairy robe, he was named Esau [sounds like “hairy” in Hebrew].

26.verse: When ·the second baby [his brother] ·was born [came out], ·he [his hand] was ·holding on to [gripping; grabbing] Esau’s heel, so that baby was named Jacob [sounds like Hebrew for “heel”; grabbing a heel is a Hebrew idiom for tricking someone]. Isaac was sixty years old when they were born.

27.verse: When the boys grew up, Esau became a ·skilled [experienced] hunter. He ·loved to be out in the fields [was a man of the fields]. But Jacob was a ·quiet [or mild; or blameless] man ·and stayed among the [living in] tents.

28.verse: Isaac loved Esau because ·he hunted the wild animals that Isaac enjoyed eating [game was in his (Isaac’s) mouth]. But Rebekah loved Jacob.

29.verse: One day Jacob was ·boiling a pot of vegetable soup [or preparing stew]. Esau came in from hunting in the fields, ·weak from hunger [famished; starving].

30.verse: So Esau said to Jacob, “Let me ·eat [gulp down] some of that red ·soup [or stuff], because I am ·weak with hunger [famished; starving].” (That is why people call him Edom [sounds like Hebrew for “red”].)

31.verse: But Jacob said, “·First [As the day; an idiom meaning, “First of all…”] ·sell [or exchange with] me your ·rights as the firstborn son [birthright; the firstborn had special inheritance rights and became the head of the family in the next generation].”

32.verse: Esau said, “I am ·almost dead from hunger [going to die]. ·If I die, all of my father’s wealth will not help me [What will my birthright be to me?].”

33.verse: But Jacob said, “First [v. 31], ·promise [swear to] me that you will give it to me.” So Esau ·made a promise to Jacob [swore to him] and ·sold [exchanged] his ·part of their father’s wealth [birthright] to Jacob.

34.verse: Then Jacob gave Esau bread and ·vegetable soup [stew], and he ate and drank, and then left. So Esau ·showed how little he cared about his rights as the firstborn son [despised/showed contempt toward his birthright; Heb. 12:16–17].

1.verse: Isaac Lies to Abimelech - Now there was a ·time of hunger [famine] in the land, besides the ·time of hunger [former famine] that happened during Abraham’s life. So Isaac went to the town of Gerar [20:1] to see Abimelech king of the Philistines.

2.verse: The LORD appeared to Isaac and said, “Don’t go down to Egypt, but ·live [settle; dwell] in the land where I tell you to live.

3.verse: ·Stay [Sojourn; Live as an alien] in this land, and I will be with you and bless you [12:3]. I will give you and your ·descendants [seed] all these lands, and I will ·keep [fulfill] the oath I made to Abraham your father.

4.verse: I will ·give you many descendants [multiply your seed], as hard to count as the stars in the sky, and I will give them all these lands. Through your ·descendants [seed] all the nations on the earth will be blessed [12:1–3].

5.verse: I will do this because your father Abraham ·obeyed me [listened to my voice]. He did what I said and obeyed my ·instructions [charge], my commands, my teachings, and my ·rules [instructions; laws].”

6.verse: So Isaac ·stayed [resided; settled] in Gerar [20:1].

7.verse: His wife Rebekah was very beautiful, and the men of that place asked Isaac about her. Isaac said, “She is my sister,” because he was afraid to tell them she was his wife. He thought they might kill him so they could have her [12:10–20; 20:1–18].

8.verse: Isaac lived there a long time. One day as Abimelech king of the Philistines looked out his window, he saw Isaac ·holding [fondling; playing with; a word related to the name Isaac] his wife Rebekah tenderly.

9.verse: Abimelech called for Isaac and said, “This woman is your wife. Why did you say she was your sister?” Isaac said to him, “I ·was afraid you would kill me so you could have [thought I might die because of] her.”

10.verse: Abimelech said, “What have you done to us? One of our ·men [people] might have ·had sexual relations [lain] with your wife. Then ·we would have been guilty of a great sin [you would have brought guilt/punishment on us].”

11.verse: So Abimelech ·warned [commanded] ·everyone [all the people], “Anyone who touches this man or his wife will be put to death.”

12.verse: Isaac Becomes Rich - Isaac planted seed in that land, and that year he gathered ·a great harvest [a hundredfold]. The LORD blessed him very much,

13.verse: and ·he [the man] became rich. He ·gathered more wealth [grew richer and richer] until he became a very rich man.

14.verse: He had so many slaves and flocks and herds that the Philistines envied him.

15.verse: So they stopped up all the wells the servants of Isaac’s father Abraham had dug. (They had dug them ·when Abraham was alive [in the days of Abraham his father].) The Philistines filled those wells with ·dirt [dust].

16.verse: And Abimelech said to Isaac, “Leave ·our country [my people] because you have become much more powerful than we are.”

17.verse: So Isaac ·left that place [went from there] and camped in the ·Valley [Wadi] of Gerar and ·lived [resided; settled] there.

18.verse: ·Long before this time Abraham [In the days of Abraham his father they] had dug many wells, but after he died, the Philistines filled them with ·dirt [dust]. So Isaac dug those wells again and gave them the same names his father had given them.

19.verse: Isaac’s servants dug a well in the ·valley [wadi], ·from which a spring of water flowed [and discovered springing/living water].

20.verse: But the ·herdsmen [shepherds] of Gerar ·argued [contended] with ·them [the shepherds of Isaac] and said, “This water is ours.” So Isaac named that well ·Argue [Contention; Hebrew: Esek] because they ·argued [contended] with him.

21.verse: Then ·his servants [they] dug another well. When the people also ·argued about it [contended], Isaac named that well ·Fight [Hebrew: Sitnah].

22.verse: He moved from there and dug another well. No one ·argued about [contended] this one, so he named it Room Enough [Hebrew: Rehoboth]. Isaac said, “Now the LORD has made room for us, and we will be ·successful [fruitful; 1:22] in this land.”

23.verse: From there Isaac went [up] to Beersheba [21:14].

24.verse: The LORD appeared to him that night and said, “I am the God of your father Abraham. Don’t be afraid, because I am with you [indicating that the covenant with Abraham would be continued with Isaac]. I will bless you and ·give you many descendants [multiply your seed] because of my servant Abraham.”

25.verse: So Isaac built an altar [a place of sacrifice] and ·worshiped [called on the name of] the LORD there. He also ·made a camp [pitched his tent] there, and his servants dug a well.

26.verse: Abimelech came from Gerar to see Isaac. He brought with him Ahuzzath, ·who advised him [his advisor/friend], and Phicol, the commander of his army.

27.verse: Isaac asked them, “Why have you come to see me? You ·were my enemy [hate me] and ·forced me to leave your country [sent me away from you].”

28.verse: They answered, “Now we ·know [clearly see] that the LORD is with you. Let us swear an oath to each other. Let us ·make [cut] an ·agreement [covenant; treaty] with you

29.verse: that since we did not ·hurt [touch] you, you will not ·hurt [harm] us. We were good to you and sent you away in peace. Now the LORD has blessed you.”

30.verse: So Isaac ·prepared food [made a banquet/feast] for them, and they all ate and drank [customary to celebrate the signing of the treaty].

31.verse: Early the next morning the men swore an oath to each other. Then Isaac sent them away, and they left in peace.

32.verse: That day Isaac’s servants came and told him about the well they had dug, saying, “We found water in that well.”

33.verse: So Isaac named it Shibah [sounds like Hebrew for “seven” or “promise”] and that city is called Beersheba [21:14] even now.

34.verse: When Esau was forty years old, he married two Hittite women—Judith daughter of Beeri and Basemath daughter of Elon.

35.verse: These women brought much ·sorrow [bitterness] to Isaac and Rebekah [because Esau had married outside the people of God].

1.verse: Jacob Tricks Isaac - When Isaac was old, his ·eyesight was poor [eyes were dim], so he could not see clearly. One day he called his older son Esau to him and said, “[My] Son.” Esau answered, “Here I am.”

2.verse: Isaac said, “I am old and don’t know ·when I might die [the day of my death].

3.verse: So take your weapons, your ·bow and arrows [quiver and your bow], and go hunting in the field for ·an animal for me to eat [game for me].

4.verse: When you prepare the tasty food that I love, bring it to me, and I will eat. Then I will bless you before I die.”

5.verse: So Esau went out in the field to hunt [for game to bring it]. Rebekah was listening as Isaac said this to his son Esau.

6.verse: She said to her son Jacob, “Listen, I heard your father saying to your brother Esau,

7.verse: ‘·Kill an animal [Bring me game] and prepare some tasty food for me to eat. Then I will bless you in the presence of the LORD before I die.’

8.verse: So ·obey [listen to] me, my son, and do what I ·tell [command] you.

9.verse: Go out to our ·goats [flock] and bring me two ·of the best young ones [choice goats]. I will prepare them just the way your father ·likes [loves] them.

10.verse: Then you will ·take the food [bring them] to your father, and he will bless you before he dies.”

11.verse: But Jacob said to his mother Rebekah, “My brother Esau is a hairy man, and I am smooth!

12.verse: If my father ·touches me, he will know I am not Esau [feels me…]. Then he will not bless me but will place a curse on me because ·I tried to trick him [he will think I am mocking him].”

13.verse: So ·Rebekah [his mother] said to him, “·If your father puts a curse on you, I will accept the blame [Let your curse be on me]. Just do what I said. Go get the goats for me.”

14.verse: So Jacob went out and got ·two goats [them] and brought them to his mother, and ·she cooked them in the special way [his mother prepared a tasty meal just as] ·Isaac [his father] ·enjoyed [loved].

15.verse: She took the best clothes of her older son Esau that were in the house and put them on the younger son Jacob.

16.verse: She also took the skins of the goats and put them on Jacob’s hands and [the smoothness of his] neck.

17.verse: Then she gave Jacob the tasty food and the bread she had made.

18.verse: Jacob went in to his father and said, “[My] Father.” And his father said, “Yes, my son. Who are you?”

19.verse: Jacob said to him, “I am Esau, your ·first son [firstborn]. I have done what you told me. Now ·sit up [get up and sit down] and eat some ·meat of the animal [game] I hunted for you. Then bless me.”

20.verse: But Isaac asked his son, “How did you find ·and kill the animal [it] so quickly?” Jacob answered, “Because the LORD your God ·helped me to find it [went before me].”

21.verse: Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come near so I can ·touch [feel] you, my son. Then I will know if you are really my son Esau [or not].”

22.verse: So Jacob came near to Isaac his father. Isaac ·touched [felt] him and said, “Your voice ·sounds like [is] Jacob’s voice, but your hands ·are hairy like [are] the hands of Esau.”

23.verse: Isaac did not ·know it was [recognize] Jacob, because his hands were hairy like Esau’s hands, so Isaac blessed him.

24.verse: Isaac asked, “Are you really my son Esau?” Jacob answered, “Yes, I am.”

25.verse: Then Isaac said, “Bring ·me the food [it to me], and I will eat ·it [my son’s game] and bless you.” So Jacob gave him the food, and he ate. Jacob gave him wine, and he drank.

26.verse: Then Isaac [his father] said to him, “My son, come near and kiss me.”

27.verse: So Jacob went to his father and kissed him. When Isaac smelled Esau’s clothes, he blessed him and said, “[See,] The smell of my son is like the smell of the field that the LORD has blessed.

28.verse: May God give you ·plenty of rain [the dew of heaven] and ·good soil [the fatness/richness/fertility of the earth] so that you will have plenty of grain and new wine.

29.verse: May nations serve you and peoples bow down to you. May you be master over your brothers, and may your mother’s sons bow down to you. May everyone who curses you be cursed, and may everyone who blesses you be blessed [12:3; Heb. 11:20].”

30.verse: Isaac [had just] finished blessing Jacob. Then, just as Jacob left his father Isaac, Esau came in from hunting.

31.verse: He also prepared some tasty food and brought it to his father. He said [to his father], “Father, rise and eat ·the food that your son killed for you [your son’s game] and then bless me.”

32.verse: Isaac his father asked him, “Who are you?” He answered, “I am your son—your firstborn son—Esau.”

33.verse: Then Isaac trembled ·greatly [violently] and said, “Then who was it that hunted ·the animals [game] and brought me food before you came? I ate it, and I blessed him, and ·it is too late now to take back my blessing [he will indeed be blessed].”

34.verse: When Esau heard the words of his father, he let out a loud and bitter cry. He said to his father, “Bless me—me, too, my father [Heb. 12:17]!”

35.verse: But Isaac said, “Your brother came and ·tricked [deceived; defrauded] me. He has taken your blessing.”

36.verse: Esau said, “Jacob [sounds like Hebrew for “heel” or “deceive”; 25:26] is the right name for him. He has ·tricked me [deceived me; been at my heel] these two times. He took away my ·share of everything you own [birthright], and now he has taken away my blessing.” Then Esau asked, “Haven’t you ·saved [reserved] a blessing for me?”

37.verse: Isaac answered [and said to Esau], “I gave Jacob the power to be master over you, and all his brothers will be his servants. And I kept ·him strong [sustained him] with grain and new wine. ·There is nothing left to give you [What can I do for you…?], my son.”

38.verse: But Esau ·continued [said to his father], “Do you have only one blessing, Father? Bless me, too, Father!” Then Esau ·began to cry out loud [lifted his voice and wept; Heb. 12:17].

39.verse: Isaac his father said to him, “You will live far away from the ·best [fatness; richness; fertility of the] land, far from the ·rain [the dew of heaven; 27:28].

40.verse: You will live by using your sword, and you will ·be a slave to [serve] your brother. But when you ·struggle [or become restless], you will break ·free from him [his yoke from your neck; Heb. 11:20].”

41.verse: After that Esau ·hated [held a grudge against] Jacob because of the blessing ·from Isaac [with which his father blessed him]. He thought ·to himself [in his heart], “·My father will soon die, and I will be sad for him [The days of mourning for my father are near]. Then I will kill Jacob [my brother].”

42.verse: Rebekah ·heard about Esau’s plan to kill Jacob [was told the words of Esau her oldest son]. So she sent for Jacob [her younger son] and ·said to [informed] him, “Listen, your brother Esau is ·comforting himself [consoling himself; or wants to execute his anger against you] by planning to kill you.

43.verse: So, my son, ·do what I say [listen to my voice]. My brother Laban is living in Haran. ·Go to him at once [Get up and flee to him]!

44.verse: ·Stay [Live; Reside] with him for a while, until your brother ·is not so angry [calms down].

45.verse: In time, your brother will not be angry, and he will forget what you did to him. Then I will send a servant to bring you back. I don’t want to lose both of my sons on the same day.”

46.verse: Then Rebekah said to Isaac, “I am ·tired of [weary of my life due to] ·Hittite women [the daughters of the Hittites]. If Jacob marries one of ·these Hittite women [the daughters of the Hittites] here in this land, ·I want to die [why would I want to live?].”

1.verse: Jacob Searches for a Wife - Isaac called Jacob and blessed him and commanded him [and said to him], “You must not marry a ·Canaanite woman [daughter of Canaan].

2.verse: ·Go [Get up and go] to the house of Bethuel, your mother’s father, in ·northwestern Mesopotamia [Paddan-aram; 25:20]. Laban, your mother’s brother, lives there. Marry one of his daughters.

3.verse: May God Almighty bless you and ·give you many children [make you fruitful and multiply you; 1:22], and may you become a ·group [assembly; congregation; company] of many peoples.

4.verse: May he give you and your ·descendants [seed] the blessing of Abraham so that you may ·own [possess] the land ·where you are now living as a stranger [of your wandering/sojourn/alien status], the land God gave to Abraham.”

5.verse: So Isaac sent Jacob to ·northwestern Mesopotamia [Paddan-aram], to Laban the brother of Rebekah. Bethuel the Aramean was the father of Laban and Rebekah, and Rebekah was the mother of Jacob and Esau.

6.verse: Esau ·learned [saw] that Isaac had blessed Jacob and sent him to ·northwestern Mesopotamia [Paddan-aram] to find a wife there. He also ·learned [saw] that Isaac had commanded Jacob not to marry a ·Canaanite woman [daughter of Canaan]

7.verse: and that Jacob had ·obeyed [listened to] his father and mother and had gone to ·northwestern Mesopotamia [Paddan-aram].

8.verse: So Esau saw that ·his father Isaac did not want his sons to marry Canaanite women [the daughters of Canaan were bad/evil in the eyes of his father Isaac].

9.verse: Now Esau already had wives, but he went to Ishmael son of Abraham, and he married Mahalath, Ishmael’s daughter. Mahalath was the sister of Nebaioth.

10.verse: Jacob’s Dream at Bethel - Jacob left Beersheba [21:14] and set out for Haran [11:31].

11.verse: When he came to a place, he spent the night there because the sun had set. He found a stone and laid his head on it ·to go to sleep [and lay down in that place].

12.verse: Jacob dreamed that there was a ·ladder [or stairway; or ramp] resting on the earth and reaching up into heaven, and he saw ·angels [messengers] of God ·going up and coming down [ascending and descending on] ·the ladder [it; John 1:51].

13.verse: Then Jacob saw the LORD standing above the ladder [28:12], and he said, “I am the LORD, the God of Abraham your grandfather, and the God of Isaac. I will give you and your ·descendants [seed] the ·land [ground] on which you are now ·sleeping [lying; 12:1–3].

14.verse: Your ·descendants [seed] will be as many as the dust of the earth [13:16]. They will spread west and east, north and south, and all the ·families [clans] of the earth will ·be blessed [or bless themselves] through you and your ·descendants [seed].

15.verse: I am with you and will ·protect [guard] you everywhere you go and will bring you back to this land. I will not ·leave [abandon; forsake] you until I have done what I have promised you.”

16.verse: Then Jacob woke from his sleep and said, “Surely the LORD is in this place, but I did not know it.”

17.verse: He was afraid and said, “This place frightens me! It is surely the house of God and the gate of heaven.”

18.verse: Jacob rose early in the morning and took the stone ·he had slept on [which was under his head] and set it up ·on its end [as a pillar; 31:13, 45; 35:14, 20; Ex. 24:4; a practice later prohibited because similar to Canaanite religion (Ex. 23:24; 34:13; Deut. 12:3)]. Then he poured olive oil on the top of it.

19.verse: ·At first [Formerly], the name of that city was Luz, but Jacob named it Bethel [“house of God”].

20.verse: Then Jacob ·made a promise [vowed a vow]. He said, “I want God to be with me and to ·protect [guard] me on this journey. I want him to give me food to eat and clothes to wear

21.verse: so I will be able to return ·in peace [or safely] to my father’s house. If the LORD does these things, he will be my God.

22.verse: This stone which I have set up ·on its end [as a pillar] will be the house of God. And I will give God ·one-tenth [a tithe] of all he gives me.”

1.verse: Jacob Arrives in Northwestern Mesopotamia - Then Jacob ·continued his journey [lifted his feet] and came to the land of the people of the East [the area of the Arameans on the northern Euphrates].

2.verse: He looked and saw a well in the field and three flocks of sheep lying nearby, because they drank water from this well. A large stone covered the mouth of the well.

3.verse: When all the flocks would gather there, ·the shepherds [they] would roll the stone away from the well and water the sheep. Then they would put the stone back in its place.

4.verse: Jacob said to the shepherds there, “My brothers, where are you from?” They answered, “We are from Haran [11:31].”

5.verse: Then Jacob asked, “Do you know Laban, ·grandson [descendant] of Nahor?” They answered, “We know him.”

6.verse: Then Jacob asked, “How is he?” They answered, “He is well. Look, his daughter Rachel is coming now with his sheep.”

7.verse: Jacob said, “But look, it is still ·the middle of the day [broad daylight]. It is not time for the sheep to be gathered for the night, so give them water and let them go back into the pasture.”

8.verse: But they said, “We cannot do that until all the flocks are gathered. Then we will roll away the stone from the mouth of the well and water the sheep.”

9.verse: While ·Jacob [he] was talking with ·the shepherds [them], Rachel came with her father’s sheep, because ·it was her job to care for the sheep [she was a shepherdess].

10.verse: When Jacob saw Laban’s daughter Rachel and Laban’s sheep, he went to the well and rolled the stone from its mouth and watered Laban’s sheep. Now Laban was the brother of Rebekah, Jacob’s mother.

11.verse: Then Jacob kissed Rachel and [lifted his voice and] cried.

12.verse: He told her that he was from her father’s family and that he was the son of Rebekah. So Rachel ran home and told her father.

13.verse: When Laban heard the news about his sister’s son Jacob, he ran to meet him. Laban hugged him and kissed him and brought him to his house, where Jacob told Laban everything that had happened.

14.verse: Then Laban said, “You are my own ·flesh and blood [bone and flesh].” Jacob Is Tricked - Jacob stayed there a month.

14.verse: So, my ·master [lord], you ·go [pass] on ahead of me, your servant. I will follow you slowly and let the animals and the children set the speed at which we travel. I will meet you, my ·master [lord], in ·Edom [Seir; 14:6].”

20.verse: He ·built [erected] an altar there and named it ·after God, the God of Israel [El-Elohe-Israel].

1.verse: Dinah Is Attacked - At this time Dinah, the daughter of Leah ·and [whom she bore to] Jacob [30:21], went out to ·visit [see; or be seen with] the ·women [daughters] of the land.

2.verse: When Shechem son of Hamor the Hivite [one of the tribes that inhabited Canaan], the ·ruler [prince] of the land, saw her, he took her and ·forced her to have sexual relations with him [lay with her and humiliated/violated her].

3.verse: ·Shechem fell in love with Dinah [His soul was bound to Dinah daugher of Jacob and he loved her], and he spoke kindly to her.

4.verse: He told his father, Hamor, “Please get this girl for me ·so I can marry her [as a wife].”

5.verse: Jacob ·learned how [heard that] ·Shechem [he] had ·disgraced [defiled; made unclean] his daughter, but since his sons were out in the field with the cattle, Jacob ·said nothing [was silent] until they came home.

7.verse: When Jacob’s sons heard what had happened, they came in from the field. They were [upset/shocked/pained and] very angry that Shechem had done ·such a wicked thing [sacrilege; folly] to Israel. It was wrong for him to ·have sexual relations [lie] with Jacob’s daughter; a thing like this should not be done.

19.verse: So ·Shechem quickly went to be circumcised [the man did not delay to do this thing] because he ·loved [delighted in] Jacob’s daughter. Now Shechem was the most ·respected [honored] man in ·his family [his father’s house].

20.verse: So Hamor and Shechem [his son] went to the gate of their city and spoke to the men of their city, saying,

Let us ·marry their women [take their daughters as wives for ourselves], and ·we can let them marry our women [give them our daughters].

22.verse: But we must agree to one thing: All our men must be circumcised as they are. Then they will agree to live in our land, and we will be one people.

29.verse: They ·took [captured and plundered] every valuable thing the people owned, even their wives and children and everything in the houses.

1.verse: Jacob in Bethel - God said to Jacob, “·Go [Rise up and go up] to the city of Bethel [12:8] and live there. Make an altar to the God who appeared to you there when you were ·running away [fleeing] from your brother Esau [28:1–22].”

4.verse: So they gave Jacob all the foreign gods ·they had [in their possession; in their hands], and the earrings ·they were wearing [on their ears], and he hid them under the ·great tree [oak; or terebinth; 12:6] near the town of Shechem.

16.verse: Rachel Dies Giving Birth - ·Jacob and his group [They] ·left [departed from] Bethel. ·Before they came to [or While still some distance from] Ephrath [near Bethlehem four miles south of Jerusalem; 35:19], Rachel began giving birth to her baby [and had hard labor],

23.verse: He had six sons by his wife Leah: Reuben, his ·first son [firstborn], then Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.

24.verse: He had two sons by his wife Rachel: Joseph and Benjamin.

25.verse: He had two sons by Rachel’s slave girl Bilhah: Dan and Naphtali.

28.verse: Isaac lived one hundred eighty years.

29.verse: So Isaac breathed his last breath and died [and was gathered to his people/relatives; 25:8] when he was very old [and full of days], and his sons Esau and Jacob buried him.

1.verse: Esau’s Family - ·This is the family history [These are the generations; 2:4] of Esau (also called Edom [25:30]).

3.verse: and Basemath [26:34], Ishmael’s daughter, the sister of Nebaioth.

4.verse: Adah gave birth to Eliphaz for Esau. Basemath gave him Reuel,

5.verse: and Oholibamah gave him Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These were Esau’s sons who were born in the land of Canaan.

6.verse: Esau took his wives, his sons, his daughters, and all the people who lived with him, his herds and other animals, and all the ·belongings [property] he had ·gotten [acquired] in Canaan, and he went to a land away from his brother Jacob.

7.verse: ·Esau and Jacob’s [For their] ·belongings [property] were becoming too many for them to live ·in the same land [together]. The land where they had ·lived [sojourned; lived as aliens] could not support both of them, because they had too many herds.

8.verse: So Esau lived in the mountains of ·Edom [Seir; 14:6]. (Esau is also named Edom [25:30].)

9.verse: ·This is the family history [These are the generations; 2:4] of Esau. He is the ·ancestor [father] of the Edomites, who live in the mountains of ·Edom [Seir].

10.verse: ·Esau’s sons were [These are the names of the sons of Esau:] Eliphaz, son of Adah and Esau, and Reuel, son of Basemath and Esau.

11.verse: Eliphaz had five sons: Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.

12.verse: Eliphaz also had a ·slave woman [concubine] named Timna, and Timna and Eliphaz gave birth to Amalek. These were Esau’s ·grandsons [descendants; sons] by his wife Adah.

15.verse: These were the ·leaders [chiefs; or clans] that came from Esau: Esau’s ·first son [firstborn] was Eliphaz. From him came these ·leaders [chiefs; or clans]: Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,

17.verse: Esau’s son Reuel was the father of these ·leaders [chiefs; or clans]: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the ·leaders [chiefs; or clans] that came from Reuel in the land of Edom. They were the grandsons of Esau’s wife Basemath.

19.verse: These were the sons of Esau (also called Edom), and these were their leaders [chiefs; or clans].

27.verse: The sons of Ezer were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.

28.verse: The sons of Dishan were Uz and Aran.

29.verse: These were the names of the Horite ·leaders [chiefs; or clans]: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,

30.verse: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These men were the ·leaders [chiefs; or clans] of the Horite families who lived in the land of Edom.

31.verse: These are the kings who ruled in the land of Edom before the Israelites ever had a king [1 Sam. 8–12]:

33.verse: When Bela died, Jobab son of Zerah became king. Jobab was from Bozrah.

34.verse: When Jobab died, Husham became king. He was from the land of the Temanites.

35.verse: When Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad, who had defeated Midian in the country of Moab, became king. Hadad was from the city of Avith.

36.verse: When Hadad died, Samlah became king. He was from Masrekah.

37.verse: When Samlah died, Shaul became king. He was from Rehoboth on the ·Euphrates River [River].

38.verse: When Shaul died, Baal-Hanan son of Acbor became king.

39.verse: When Baal-Hanan son of Acbor died, Hadad became king. He was from the city of Pau. His wife’s name was Mehetabel daughter of Matred, who was the daughter of Me-Zahab.

40.verse: These Edomite ·leaders [chiefs; or clans], listed by their ·families [clans] and regions, came from Esau. Their names were Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,

43.verse: Magdiel, and Iram. They were the ·leaders [chiefs; or clans] of Edom. (Esau was the father of the Edomites.) The area where each of these ·families [clans] lived was named after that ·family [clan].

1.verse: Joseph the Dreamer - Jacob ·lived [settled] in the land of Canaan, where his father had ·lived [sojourned; lived as an alien].

2.verse: ·This is the family history [These are the generations; 2:4] of Jacob: Joseph was a young man, seventeen years old. He and his brothers, the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, his father’s wives, ·cared for [shepherded] the flocks. Joseph was a ·helper [assistant; youth] to his brothers. Joseph gave his father bad reports about his brothers.

3.verse: Since Joseph was born when his father Israel [Jacob’s other name] was old, Israel loved him more than his other sons. He made Joseph a special robe with long sleeves [traditionally a multicolored robe].

4.verse: When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father loved him more than he loved them, they hated their brother and could not speak to him ·politely [civilly; peacefully].

5.verse: One time Joseph had a dream, and when he told his brothers about it, they hated him even more.

6.verse: Joseph said, “Listen to the dream I ·had [dreamed].

7.verse: We were in the field tying ·bundles [sheaves] of wheat together. My ·bundle [sheaf] rose and stood upright, and your ·bundles [sheaves] of wheat gathered around it and bowed down to it.”

8.verse: His brothers said, “Do you really think you will be king over us? Do you truly think you will ·rule over [dominate] us?” His brothers hated him even more because of his dreams and what he had said.

9.verse: Then Joseph had another dream, and he told his brothers about it also. He said, “Listen, I had another dream. I saw the sun, moon, and eleven stars bowing down to me.”

10.verse: Joseph also told his father about this dream, but his father ·scolded [rebuked] him, saying, “What kind of dream is this? Do you really believe that your mother, your brothers, and I will bow down to you?”

13.verse: Israel said to Joseph, “·Go to Shechem where your brothers are grazing the flocks [Are not your brothers shepherding in Shechem? Go and I will send you to them].” Joseph answered, “I will go.”

14.verse: His father said, “Go and see ·if your brothers and the flocks are all right [after the welfare of your brothers and the flocks]. Then come back and ·tell me [give me a report].” So Joseph’s father sent him from the Valley of Hebron [13:18]. When Joseph came to Shechem,

15.verse: a man found him wandering in the field and asked him, “What are you looking for?”

16.verse: Joseph answered, “I am looking for my brothers. Can you tell me where they are ·grazing [shepherding] the flocks?”

17.verse: The man said, “They have already gone. I heard them say they were going to Dothan [a small town thirteen miles north of Shechem].” So Joseph went to look for his brothers and found them in Dothan.

18.verse: Joseph Sold into Slavery - Joseph’s brothers saw him coming from far away. Before he reached them, they ·made a plan [conspired] to kill him.

19.verse: They said to each other, “Here comes that dreamer.

20.verse: Let’s ·kill [murder] him and throw his body into one of the ·wells [pits; cisterns]. We can tell our father that a wild animal ·killed [ate] him. Then we will see what will become of his dreams.”

23.verse: So when Joseph came to his brothers, they ·pulled [stripped] off his robe with long sleeves [37:3]

25.verse: ·While Joseph was in the well, the brothers [They] sat down to eat. When they ·looked up [lifted their eyes], they saw a ·group [caravan] of Ishmaelites traveling from Gilead to Egypt. Their camels were carrying spices, balm, and myrrh.

28.verse: So when the Midianite traders [Midian is part of the Ishmaelite nation; Judg. 8:22, 24] came by, ·the brothers took Joseph out [they drew him and lifted him up out] of the ·well [pit; cistern] and sold him to the Ishmaelites for ·eight ounces [twenty pieces] of silver [the price of a slave at the time]. And the Ishmaelites took him to Egypt.

30.verse: Then he went back to his brothers and said, “The boy is not there! ·What shall I do [And as for me, where should I go]?”

31.verse: ·The brothers killed [They took the robe and slaughtered] a goat and dipped Joseph’s robe in its blood.

33.verse: ·Jacob looked it over [He recognized it] and said, “It is my son’s robe! Some ·savage [evil] animal has eaten him. My son Joseph has been torn to pieces!”

34.verse: Then Jacob tore his clothes and put ·on rough cloth [burlap/sackcloth on his loins; to show he was upset], and he continued ·to be sad about [mourn for] his son for ·a long time [many days].

35.verse: All of his sons and daughters tried to ·comfort [console] him, but he could not be ·comforted [consoled]. He said, “I will ·be sad about my son until the day I die [I will go down to Sheol/the grave mourning my son].” So ·Jacob [his father] cried for his son Joseph.

36.verse: Meanwhile the Midianites who had bought Joseph had taken him to Egypt. There they sold him to Potiphar, an officer to ·the king of Egypt [Pharaoh] and captain of the palace guard and chief ·butcher [or executioner; a high Egyptian official].

1.verse: Judah and Tamar - About that time, Judah ·left [went down from] his brothers and went to stay with a man named Hirah in the town of Adullam [a Canaanite city nine miles northwest of Hebron].

2.verse: There Judah met a Canaanite girl, the daughter of a man named Shua, and married her. Judah ·had sexual relations with [went to] her,

3.verse: and she ·became pregnant [conceived] and gave birth to a son, whom Judah named Er.

4.verse: Later she gave birth to another son and named him Onan.

5.verse: Still later she had another son and named him Shelah. She was at Kezib [“deceiving”; a town near Adullam; probably the same as Aczib; Josh. 15:44] when this third son was born.

6.verse: Judah ·chose [took] a girl named Tamar to be the wife of his ·first son [firstborn] Er.

7.verse: But Er, Judah’s ·oldest son [firstborn], did ·what the LORD said was evil [evil in the eyes/sight of the LORD] so the LORD killed him.

8.verse: Then Judah said to Er’s brother Onan, “Go and have sexual relations with your dead brother’s wife. It is your duty to ·provide children for your brother in this way [raise up a seed for your brother; Deut. 25:5–10].”

9.verse: But Onan knew that the ·children [seed] would not belong to him, so when he ·was supposed to have sexual relations with [he went to] Tamar he ·did not complete the sex act [spilled his seed on the ground], ·making it impossible for Tamar to become pregnant and for Er to have descendants [so that he did not give a descendant/seed to his brother].

10.verse: ·The LORD was displeased by this wicked thing Onan had done [What he did was evil in the eyes/sight of the LORD], so he killed Onan also.

11.verse: Then Judah said to his daughter-in-law Tamar, “·Go back to live in your father’s house, and don’t marry [Remain a widow in your father’s house] until my young son Shelah grows up.” Judah was afraid that Shelah also would die like his brothers. So Tamar returned to her father’s home.

12.verse: After a long time Judah’s wife, the daughter of Shua, died. After Judah ·had gotten over his sorrow [was comforted], he went to Timnah [a town south of Hebron] to his ·men who were cutting the wool from his sheep [sheepshearers]. His friend Hirah from Adullam went with him.

13.verse: Tamar learned that Judah, her father-in-law, was going to Timnah to cut the wool from his sheep.

14.verse: So she took off the clothes that showed she was a widow and covered her face with a veil ·to hide who she was [and wrapped herself up; perhaps indicating a woman was a prostitute; see v. 15]. Then she sat down by the gate of Enaim on the road to Timnah. She did this because Judah’s younger son Shelah had grown up, but Judah had not ·made plans for her to marry him [given her to him as a wife].

15.verse: When Judah saw her, he thought she was a prostitute, because she had covered her face with a veil.

16.verse: So Judah went to her [on the road side/way] and said, “Let me ·have sexual relations with [come to] you.” He did not know that she was Tamar, his daughter-in-law. She asked, “What will you ·give [pay] me if I let you ·have sexual relations with [come to] me?”

17.verse: Judah answered, “I will send you a young goat from my flock.” She answered, “First give me ·something to keep as a deposit [a pledge] until you send the goat.”

18.verse: Judah asked, “What do you want me to give you as a ·deposit [pledge]?” Tamar answered, “Give me your ·seal [signet] and its cord, and give me your ·walking stick [staff; all items that could identify a person].” So Judah gave these things to her. Then ·Judah and Tamar had sexual relations, and Tamar became pregnant [he went to her and she conceived].
